Morris Dees: Scourge of KKK Sees Shades of Gray
LaserPhoto NY304 of Oct. 3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Black-and-white. Usually it means plain, explicit, uncomplicated. But in his law office, where the white pages of statute books were blackened by a firebomb, Morris Dees somehow keeps seeing shades of gray. Dees, the founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center and its chief counsel in trials that have destroyed Ku Klux Klan organizations, wants to understand his bitter adversaries - even the ones who've tried to kill him. ``A lot of these people have paranoid personalities bred from basically family problems when they were children,'' he says. ``They're looking for love and affection.'' ``If you look at a Klan roster, just about everybody ... can be an exalted something. It makes them feel important.'' White supremacists chafe at such cool analysis, and at least three racist groups have put Dees at or near the top of their hit lists. A display case in his offices holds charred law books and a melted clock, reminders of the 1983 firebombing by Klansmen. In a case set for trial Monday in Portland, Ore., the 53-year-old white Alabama lawyer is suing an organization called the White Aryan Resistance for allegedly inciting skinheads to fatally beat an African man there. A lawsuit he brought in 1984 in the lynching of a black teen-ager in Mobile, Ala., resulted in a judgment that bankrupted the United Klans of America. The victim's mother, Buelah Mae Donald, received title to the Klan's national headquarters. Dees pursued the case with zeal - and yet he wept, along with others, when one of the killers stood up at the end of the trial and begged Mrs. Donald's forgiveness. ``I just think once you come face-to-face with this person you stalk, and their families ... that's a catharsis that a lot of people go through,'' he said. Morris Dees grew up, blond-haired and blue-eyed, in Alabama cotton country. When asked the source of the righteous anger that seems to underlie the law center, he tells a story of his youth. He was 16 and his father sent him to accompany a tractor driver on the farm, a black man named Clarence, to a court appearance. Clarence had been charged with drunken driving, but Dees believed his story: ``His car had a tie rod come loose and he'd hit a concrete median and knocked himself dizzy.'' The justice of the peace operated out of a store, and during the ``trial,'' Dees said, ``he never quit serving crackers and cheese and Cokes across the counter.'' Guilty was the inevitable ruling. ``The fine was over $100. Clarence didn't have that kind of money,'' Dees said. ``I don't know, that kind of set me on wanting to become a lawyer.'' Dees graduated from the University of Alabama and its law school. While still a student, he set up a lucrative birthday cake delivery service, and later sold books by direct mail. He and a partner sold the business for a reported $6 million. Dees next put his direct-mail skills to work raising millions for George McGovern's Democratic presidential campaign in 1972, then used the mailing lists to appeal for help on his own project, the fledgling Southern Poverty Law Center. The center grew out of ``his determination that there was an enormous gap in legal defense in certain kinds of cases,'' said Julian Bond, a black civil rights leader from Georgia who became the center's first board chairman. What drives Morris Dees? ``A very well-developed sense of outrage,'' said Bond, now a professor and broadcaster in Washington, D.C. ``He knows the legal system can be used to right wrongs.'' The law center, which now has an endowment of $30 million and a $4 million annual budget, has taken on death penalty, voting rights, employment discrimination and other cases, but is best known for hauling the Klan and similar groups into court. Klanwatch, a handful of investigators at the Montgomery law center backed up by informants around the country, produces a bi-monthly ``Intelligence Report'' on hate group activities, which is sent to 4,000 police agencies. White robes reflected by a fiery cross, the fear reflected on black faces in the night, in the ``Intelligence Report'' these stark events are reduced to column upon column of statistics, names and dates. Black-and-white becomes gray again. ``It appears to be good solid information,'' said Lt. Robert McCulley of the Memphis, Tenn., police. ``Information is hard to come by. You don't go into a bookstore and walk to the section labeled `Terrorism.' '' To enter the Southern Poverty Law Center, a visitor climbs steps walled with stone past a granite monument to civil rights martyrs. The front door is unlocked electronically and, inside, a receptionist sits at a video security system. ``It's a necessary bunker,'' Bond said. ``If you do this work from the safety of New York City, it's one thing. But if you're right in the heart of the beast, a sensible person takes precautions.'' And Dees does. He varies his route and schedule to and from work. He avoids alleys. ``Demon Dees!'' Louis Beam, a Texas neo-Nazi, once shouted during questioning by his nemesis in one case. Beam challenged Dees to a duel. Exorcising the demon with a simple gunshot apparently was not enough for members of The Order, which murdered Denver talk show host Alan Berg. ``The preliminary plan called for kidnapping Dees, interrogating him, then flaying him - peeling his skin off his body - before killing him,'' wrote Kevin Flynn and Gary Gerhardt in their book, ``The Silent Brotherhood.'' In an otherwise even-toned interview, the only strong profanity came when the soft-spoken Dees was asked if he doesn't expect one day to become another name on the law center's memorial. ``Man, I don't want to be a martyr to anybody's (expletive) cause,'' he said. ``I didn't get into this thing for a cause.'' The law center began with a variety of suits: challenging unhealthy working conditions in textile plants, representing death row inmates and others. Dees first went up against the white supremacists in 1979, agreeing to represent a black marcher attacked during a peaceful demonstration in Decatur, Ala. Clubbed by KKK counterdemonstrators, the man tried to defend himself with a registered gun, Dees said. An all-white jury convicted him. Dees thought back to Clarence, and his day in court: ``Nothing had really changed.'' But it was about to. He filed a civil lawsuit against the Klansmen. Evidence uncovered by Klanwatch led to federal indictments against 10 Klansmen, and the suit ended in a settlement that, among other things, required the whites to attend a race relations class. The class was taught earlier this year by the Rev. Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, who is black. ``One of the Klansmen,'' Dees said, ``the day of the demonstration he had a club in his hand ... Eleven years later, he's standing there holding hands with Dr. Lowery in a prayer. ``And saying, `Maybe I was misguided back then, and we could have solved our problems in a different way.' '' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atanta.

DOC.HEAD: Free-Speech Claim in Skinhead Case Called `Baloney'; ACLU Monitoring
With PM-Klan's Nemesis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist accused in a lawsuit of inciting skinheads to commit a racially motivated killing in Portland, Ore., says he was merely exercising his First Amendment rights. The suit, which seeks damages from the group White Aryan Resistance, or WAR, and four individuals, is merely ``a roundabout way of cutting off freedom of speech, freedom of association and even freedom of assembly,'' said Tom Metzger, the organization's leader and a defendant. The Oregon office of the American Civil Liberties Union plans to monitor the trial, set to begin Monday in Portland. Plaintiff's lawyer Morris Dees calls Metzger's claims ``baloney.'' The civil case follows the criminal conviction of three skinheads in the 1988 beating death of Mulugeta Seraw, a 27-year-old Ethiopian who was living and working in Portland. Seraw's skull was fractured with a baseball bat. Dees' Montgomery, Ala.-based Southern Poverty Law Center sued on behalf of Seraw's estate. In the past, the center has won millions in judgments by suing hate groups and their leaders, arguing that they are responsible for damage and injuries done at their behest, just as a corporation can be held liable for employees' actions. The suit contends Metzger and his son John have recruited skinheads to WAR in recent years, and that through agents they sent to Portland, they provided a skinhead group called East Side White Pride with racist materials promoting violence against blacks and Jews. Seraw's killers were members of East Side White Pride. Further, the suit - which was joined by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith - claims WAR agents were in contact with the Metzgers in Fallbrook, Calif., met with the skinheads and encouraged them to harm blacks. ``The allegations of personal involvement ... are totally nonsense,'' Metzger said. ``It's something that Mr. Dees has dreamed up.'' Dees said he has letters and phone records linking the Metzgers and their ``agents'' in Portland, as well as ``a damning affidavit.'' In it, one of the agents, Michael Barrett, tells of taking five baseball bats to Portland, of keeping close contact with the Metzgers, and of meeting with East Side White Pride skinheads. ``We told them to use violence if they got an opportunity, and to be sure and beat the hell out of the enemy,'' Barrett said in the affidavit. ``We were telling them what Tom and John Metzger told us to say.''

DOC.HEAD: A Courtly Gentleman Retires From Congress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: He arrived in time for the tidal wave of Great Society activism, championed social concerns during the penny-pinching Reagan era and leaves as he came, fighting for civil rights. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, 83, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, is a black man who never played racial politics; a liberal who inspires affection among conservatives; a courtly gentleman who rarely gives up or gives in. The diminutive, soft-spoken Democrat is retiring this year after 28 years in Congress representing Watts, the Los Angeles neighborhood notorious for the riots that tore it apart in the 1960s. In the brave new Capitol Hill world of sound bites, cynicism and big money, the void left by Hawkins' departure may not be immediately obvious. But there will be one. Ask any education, labor or civil rights lobbyist; the senior Republican on his committee; even Rep. Tom Downey, who bested him in a recent dispute over how to channel child-care money to states and parents. ``This institution is going to miss him terribly,'' said Downey, D-N.Y. ``He has been a relentless pursuer of social justice,'' said Michael Edwards, chief lobbyist for the National Education Association. ``He has very deeply held principles and a great sense of mission. And yet he was always able to bring people together.'' Hawkins' basic philosophy - that government must help its less fortunate citizens - hasn't changed much since he was elected to the California Assembly in 1934. ``I truly believe every person in our country is entitled to equal opportunities. If we give them those opportunities, it will help everybody else. That's good, ordinary common sense,'' he said in an interview last week. The son of a British-born adventurer who moved his family to the United States after exploring Africa, Hawkins won his House seat in 1962. He was the first black member from a Western state, and one of the first things he did was sponsor the equal employment section of the landmark 1964 Civil Rights Act. It was an early triumph in a congressional career that has spanned eras of plenty and parsimony, pendulum swings in political thought, and the inevitable mixture of achievements and disappointments. Chief among the latter was the 1978 Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill, which put forth an admirable goal but lost a federal job guarantee before passage. ``It's been an outright failure in terms of implementation,'' Hawkins said bluntly. ``No one's taken it seriously, beginning with the Carter administration.'' The widely supported 1988 welfare reform law, with its requirement that some recipients take jobs, was another setback from Hawkins' perspective. Workfare is ``a punitive approach to forcing people off the rolls,'' he declared on the floor. It was an unusually harsh stand for a man who, despite his enduring New Deal concerns, generally prefers compromise to confrontation. Hawkins' grasp of political reality was put to the test in 1984, when he became committee chairman amid rampant conservatism and a scarcity of domestic resources. For the most part he adapted well, building coalitions and inching ahead where possible. ``If you only have a potato, the only thing you can make is potato soup. You can't make stew,'' said Bob McGlotten, chief lobbyist for the AFL-CIO. ``Under severe circumstances, Gus has done a tremendous job to make sure the educational systems in our society don't fall apart.'' The kind of money Hawkins wanted to spend on education and programs for disadvantaged children wasn't available, but he settled for modest gains and was rewarded with near-unanimous passage of many major education bills. There was far more contention in the labor area, including protracted battles over raising the minimum wage and guaranteeing unpaid family leaves to workers. But civility was always the order of the day. ``We don't have any animosity. We have differences,'' said Fred Krebs, manager of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce's labor and human resources department. The same civility characterized Hawkins' relations with Republicans on the committee, who recently threw him a retirement party. Among his gifts was a homemade gavel to crack crabs and a gag picture of Downey with a forged inscription that said ``I really enjoyed working closely with you.'' ``I'm very saddened that he is leaving,'' said Rep. Bill Goodling, R-Pa., the senior Republican on Hawkins' committee. ``He is one of the finest gentlemen I've ever met.'' The two men had a close partnership, with the chairman often testing his ideas on Goodling and molding them to attract broader support. ``If he doesn't agree with what I'm trying to do, I try to find out why. I know I will get the same disagreements from others,'' Hawkins said. ``If I can make modifications, we'll get something done. If you are really interested in results, why not be cooperative?'' Hawkins, so light-skinned he is often thought to be white, has never chaired the Congressional Black Caucus and prefers to cast issues in economic rather than racial terms. He has promoted education, health care and nutrition for the needy, and been instrumental in securing passage of many civil ights laws that opened up opportunities for minorities and others. Ironically, as he leaves Congress, Hawkins is once again trying to restore some of the protections he first fought for in 1964. Bush is threatening to veto this year's Kennedy-Hawkins civil rights bill, although Hawkins said he amended it 22 times to try to please the administration. ``In some ways we're back where we were,'' Hawkins said. ``It is discouraging, but not to the point where we're giving up. You have this ebb and flow in American politics... You win a few and you lose a few. By and large you try to be incremental in making advances.'' When Hawkins retires, he won't vanish onto the Chesapeake Bay in his beloved fishing boat. Instead he intends to speak, volunteer and organize on behalf of Job Corps, Head Start and other programs he fostered in Congress. ``You don't have to be in elective office to make a difference,'' Hawkins said. ``There's lots of things to do, and in between I'll do a little fishing.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Children Orphaned or Abandoned in Romania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Stan Barbu is 3 and runs on his knees because the parents who abandoned him will not let surgeons fix his twisted legs. he 50 other children in the orphanage are blind, retarded or maimed. They are the dregs of tens of thousands of abandoned or orphaned children who owe their plight to Nicolae Ceausescu's obsession with population growth. Ten months after the Commuist dictator was overthrown and executed, no one knows just how many children languish in Romania's 78 orphanages and in dozens of hospitals. The government says there may be 60,000 in a total population of 23 million, but other estimates range up to 100,000. What to do with them has yet to be decided. Some foreigners believe adoption is part of the answer. Stan is pale and fair-haired, with a broad grin and bright eyes that make his crippling infirmities difficult to believe. His fingers and toes are grown together and his legs bend inward in arcs so severe that he must walk and run on his knees. He delights in showing visitors what he can do. Although Stan's parents abandoned him two years ago, Romanian law gives them the right to say whether he should have surgery. They have refused, and ``there's nothing we can do but watch him suffer'' unless the law is changed, one of his nurses said. Ceausescu, put to death last Christmas Day, did not permit contraception and abortion was illegal, with few exceptions. Women were required to have regular medical examinations to determine whether they were pregnant. Couples were encouraged to have at least four children each, but Ceausescu's economic policies made it difficult to afford more than one. Parents abandoned tens of thousands of children to state institutions. Dr. Emil Tomescu, deputy health minister, estimates no more than 3 percent of the children in orphanages actually are orphans. Of the approximately 800 Romanian children diagnosed this year as having AIDS, most are abandoned. Doctors said the fatal disease was spread among them through transfusions of infected blood given before Romania had blood-screening equipment. Tomescu said he expected legalized abortion, new family planning centers and an improved economy to help ease the problem of abandoned children and orphans. Dr. Marghareta Creteanu, director of Stan's ward at the St. Catherine Home for Children in Bucharest, said the institution had admitted only 120 children since January, about half the number of the same period in 1989. Barry Child of Orphanages Trust, a British organization that aids Romania, said his organization plans to buy some houses and put two to four children in each, along with subsidized house parents helped by British volunteers. ``This way, fewer would have to live in orphanages'' and fewer might go to orphanages, where he said ``conditions are absolutely terrible.'' Child said the most serious problem in orphanages was understaffing, ``so we first want to provide groups . . . to teach the Romanian staff what to do to take good care of the children.'' Liz Brown, team leader of four young Scottish nurses working as Orphanages Trust volunteers, said: ``A head nurse won't just jump in and help . . . as we would in other countries, and this exacerbates the problem.'' The deputy health minister, Tomescu, said the government recognized the problem and had decided to increase the nurse-child ratio from 1 to 23 to 1 nurse for each 10 children. Mariana Gheorghiu, a nurse at the Bucharest home, said the new policy had not yet taken affect and ``things haven't really changed much, despite the efforts of some dedicated people who came here to help.'' ``We have more milk and meat, but there is a grave crisis in terms of personnel . . . too many kids, too few nurses,'' she said. As she spoke, Ms. Gheorghiu changed the diaper of Gabriela, who was 9 months old and dying of pneumonia. St. Catherine's is known as one of the best children's homes in Romania. Conditions there are poorer than in the West, but far better than at other Romanian orphanages. David Livianu, director of the American Center for Romanian Adoptable Children, said adoption is ``their only way out of a lifetime of struggle and indignity.'' He took the photographs of 16 children with him to the United States in August, and said adoptive parents awaited them in the United States. Livianu recently established an adoption center and his organization also has offices in the Health Ministry. ``It can cost people up to $15,000 to come here, stay in Romania for months and pay middlemen and lawyers en route to adopting a child,'' he said. ``We want to . . . encourage people to instead make donations, which can be used to buy much-needed biomedical equipment such as incubators.'' Adoption was simplified in August by repeal of a law that required presidential approval of all adoptions. Under the new law, adoptions are handled by local courts and need only the approval of child-care specialists and the child's parents, if they are alive. Dan Koch, 36, the first American to adopt under the new law, said he ``encountered very little'' bureaucratic delay or corruption. ``I believe it would have taken longer and been more complicated . . . back home,'' said Koch, who works for the Delaware state insurance commission. He returned to his wife, Kathleen, with 3-year-old Ioan, now named John Nicholas.

DOC.HEAD: Souter: The More Things Change, the More He Stays the Same
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: His presumed ideology has been condemned on all sides, his housekeeping has been derided and his neckties have been likened to dishrags, but David Souter's friends say he is a man content with himself who won't change when he joins the Supreme Court this week. ``Goodness no, that's like saying that Gibraltar could be changed by a rainstorm,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., who preceded Souter as state attorney general and sat behind him all through Senate confirmation hearings. ``David Souter's foundations and values have been built over 51 years,'' Rudman said. ``David hasn't changed at all and will not change at all.'' The 51-year-old ascetic bachelor's life has been turned upside down in the past few months as he went from a little-known regional jurist to one of the nation's nine most powerful judges. Liberals and conservatives alike have voiced suspicions that he'll vote against them on abortion, civil rights and other social issues. Journalists have scrutinized everything from his suits to how he'll cope with crime, noise and high real estate prices in the nation's capital. But friends say he ultimately will be the soft-spoken, even-tempered man he always has been whether he is in Weare, N.H., or Washington, where he moved this weekend to get ready to join the court Tuesday. ``He's in a constant whirl of change, but he will be himself wherever he is. ... He is satisfied with who he is,'' said Concord lawyer Tom Rath, Souter's deputy and successor as attorney general. Throughout a barrage of public and media scrutiny that began when President Bush nominated him to the court July 23, Souter remained polite, almost courtly, to anyone who begged a minute. ``No trouble at all,'' he told a apologetic reporter who called him at his Weare farmhouse - the phone number is still in the book - the day he returned from Senate Judiciary Committee hearings. ``That's David Souter,'' Rudman said. ``He is without a doubt one of the most self-effacing, gracious people I have ever met.'' But, Rath noted, ``I think there were moments when that sort of basic nature of him - good natured, unfailingly courteous - was tested.'' Some of those moments included an inventory of Souter's ancient kitchen appliances made by reporters peeking through his windows while he was in Washington meeting senators. Souter joked about it: ``When I think of all the things I should have left out if I'd known somebody was going to peek - but I'll never have that chance again.'' In reality, he was annoyed, Rudman and Rath said. ``He didn't like that and he felt people overstepped their bounds, but I think he understood that for a few weeks or months he'd have to endure it,'' Rudman said. Rath said friends tried to make sure that Souter's courtesy didn't allow people to take advantage of him. ``I got angry a couple of times, very angry the first Friday he got back and ... he went over to see his mother,'' said Rath, who acted as Souter's press agent and personal sentry after the nomination. Souter, he recalled, went in the back door of his mother's home in a Concord retirement community. Immediately, reporters converged on the front entrance. ``The man hadn't even seen his mother and four or five reporters were knocking on his door. I said, `Look, fellows, come over here and interview me.' '' Even well-wishing neighbors created some problems, although Souter and Rath said their support was appreciated. ``He told me the other day that he parked his car at the post office to mail a package and it took him 45 minutes to get from his car to the window,'' Rath said. ``People are warm and friendly and such, but it gets wearing.'' Everyone in Souter's circle are happy that the attention is abating. ``I think there's a feeling of enormous relief,'' Rath said. ``This is a man who likes his work. And the fact that he hasn't been able to work for the last 2{ months has been hard.'' Once he goes back to work, he'll stay there, eschewing the Washington social scene that already has chosen him one of its most eligible bachelors, Rudman predicted. ``He will be here as he was in New Hampshire, essentially extraordinarily hard-working,'' he said. ``If anybody in this city thinks that those phonies who send him those power invitations will get their hands on him, they are in for one terrible disappointment,'' said Rudman, whose dislike for the social whirl is well known. ``As of Monday at 5 p.m.,'' when Souter will take the first of two oaths of office, Rudman said, ``he will essentially disappear as a person who is seen in the scene here in this city.''

DOC.HEAD: Despite Prospects of Bigger Role, Japan's Military Still An Outcast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Fabled in history but reviled today, Japan's military leads the life of a second-class citizen in this country where pacifism is not just a policy but a constitutional vow. On Sunday, the Self Defense Forces celebrated their 36th anniversary on a remote parade ground in Asaka, just north of Tokyo. The field bristled with the latest surface-to-air missiles, tanks and other high-tech weapons. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, reviewing the troops, assured them the nation stood behind their ``noble and important mission.'' But on the streets of Japan, soldiers are often harassed as ``tax thiefs.'' And in Parliament, the military's voice is rarely heard, despite the governing conservative party's push for a more active military role overseas in response to the Persian Gulf crisis. Indeed, custom dictates that top military officials are not even invited to government policy-making meetings. An audience with the emperor, an honor treasured by new Cabinet ministers, is denied the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff. ``Sentiment here is still very strong 45 years after the war. People detest things military,'' said Masashi Nishihara, a professor at Japan's Defense Academy. ``Even today, the SDF does not make its views known officially.'' Tomohisa Sakanaka, a defense expert at Aoyama Gakuin University, said political leaders are ``very scared of treating the military in an honored way. They'd prefer to disengage them from the mainstream.'' The stated mission of the military's 275,000 ground, sea and air forces is the defense of Japan and its sea lanes to a distance of 1,000 miles, ostensibly against Communist aggression in the Far East. The military's 1,220 tanks, 55 destroyers, 14 submarines and 320 jet fighters are prevented from going farther by Japan's constitution, which bars the use of force overseas. The all-volunteer force was formed as part of the U.S. security umbrella, which includes about 50,000 troops stationed here. But the military's mission was conceived in 1954, when the Cold War was in full swing and Japan had barely recovered from the ashes of World War II. Today, this resource-poor country, whose status as the world's No. 2 economy rests on a far-flung network of raw-material imports, faces the task of redefining what constitutes its national security. The danger at home has receded in the face of Soviet liberalization and Japan's new detente with China and North Korea. And dangers abroad are growing, as signaled by the crisis in the Middle East, from where Japan gets 70 percent of its oil. As a result, Parliament will be hotly debating this fall just how far self-defense should extend. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has proposed sending a smal number of non-combat troops to the Persian Gulf under the U.N. flag. And he insists ``the people will listen to me'' about the need to expand the military's mission. He'd better have a good explanation. In museums and television dramas, the brave samurai of yesteryear is as popular as ever. But modern Japan remains haunted by darker preoccupations: the nation's more than 1,000 years of military rule, when ruthless warlords dominated civil administrators and emperor alike. It happened once too often. In the 1930s, militarists again rose up and broke free of civilian control, shattering Japan's shaky first attempt at constitutional democracy. The result was the catastrophic Pacific War, the only defeat suffered by this intensely proud nation on its own soil. Japan's surrender brought a psychological about-face. The U.S.-imposed constitution that ``forever'' forbids war remains an unyielding article of faith here. Perhaps the war's most enduring legacy, though, was that it erased from many Japanese minds the idea of military power as a necessity. ``A whole generation of Japanese has grown up without any consciousness of the need for military strength,'' said Minoru Hirano, a vice principal at a Tokyo high school. Much of the blame for that can be laid on the nation's educators, who were deeply shamed over the role they played in indoctrinating prewar youth to die for the emperor, said Sakanaka, the defense expert. Today, the main slogan of the powerful Nikkyoso teachers union remains, ``Never send our students to the battlefield again.'' Other Asian nations, still bitter over Japan's brutal wartime incursions into China, Korea, the Philippines and other countries, view the slightest rumblings of Japanese militarism with the same fear that Europe has traditionally felt toward a resurgent Germany. Almost all experts here agree that a newly aggressive Japan is unlikely, despite its ranking among the world's top five military spenders at $31 billion a year. Surveys since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait consistently show that more than 60 percent of Japanese oppose an overseas role for the military. ``Because we've been at peace for so long and no one's conscious of any danger, none of us really think about the Self Defense Forces at all,'' said Manabu Watanabe, 21, one of a group of college students munching hamburgers at a Wendy's in Tokyo. Partly because of such sentiments, officials acknowledge difficulty in annually recruiting 20,000 new soldiers from Japan's population more than 120 million people. That's despite starting wages of about $880 a month, 21 percent higher than for U.S. soldiers. Moreover, some who join are stung by U.S. criticism that Japan has shirked its global responsibilities by sending money but few men to the Persian Gulf. ``We can't be full members of the free world society,'' said an officer quoted recently in local news, ``if we do not shed blood to protect world security.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Japan's Constitution Leaves Room for Overseas Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Japan-Military
DOC.TEXT: Japan's ``peace'' constitution, the focus of angry debate over the use of force overseas, actually leaves plenty of room for dispatching troops to the Persian Gulf, analysts say. In fact, they point out, the existence of Japan's Self Defense Forces already violates the constitution. The real battleground is political, not legal, the experts say. ``I don't think the constitution is a real constraint,'' said Seizaburo Sato, a Tokyo University politics professor. ``What's lacking is courageous leadership on the part of the prime minister.'' The key constitutional provision, adopted under the U.S. occupation after World War II, is Article 9. It states that ``the Japanese people forever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation and the threat or use of force as a means of settling international disputes.'' ``In order to accomplish the aim of the preceding paragraph,'' it continues, ``land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential, will never be maintained.'' In the 1950s, the government decided that the ban on land, sea and air forces was not intended to deprive the nation of its sovereign right to self-defense. The Self Defense Forces were born. Today, scholars say, the ruling conservative party, the Liberal Democrats, could just as easily reinterpret Article 9 to justify a combat role for Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's proposed U.N. Peace Cooperation Corps - particularly in view of other countervailing constitutional provisions. The constitution's preamble, for example, says that Japan seeks an honorable place in international society and its struggle against oppression. ``If we pay attention to that clause it means we should be involved in United Nations peacekeeping,'' even if that means battle, said Masashi Nishihara, a professor at Japan's Defense Academy. ``Also, Article 2 of the U.N. charter describes the principles of each member nation. It says members should not resort to the threat or use of force. It matches our Article 9. ``So if we are going to work under the U.N. flag, then such a collective security action does not constitute the threat or use of force,'' he said. Nonetheless, the government insists the peace corps will be used only for non-combat activities, such as transportation. Critics say this is mostly because of heavy public opinion against an overseas military role and the ruling party's weakness in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Elections Bad News for Ecologists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The sweeping victories by conservatives in last week's congressional and gubernatorial races will mean bad news for the rain forest and its defenders, environmentalists say. Conservatives won a large majority in last week's voting, and showed special strength in the nine states of the Amazon region. ``Almost all . . . are totally opposed to ecological concerns and rational development,'' Fernando Gabeira, a leader of Brazil's small Green Party, said over the weekend. The federal government sets most environmental policy, but political scientist David Fleischer of the University of Brasilia noted: ``Almost all policy enforcement is carried out by local authorities. If they show no interest in protecting the environment, decisions at the federal level lose much of their impact.'' Right-wing candidates for governor won outright victories in three of the nine states and were headed for Nov. 25 runoffs in the other six. Only in two small states, Acre and Amapa, did pro-ecology candidates even get to the runoffs. Candidates had to win an absolute majority to take a first-round victory. In congressional races, conservatives won at least 11 of the 13 senate chairs at stake in the Amazon region and all but a few of the house seats. Rightist populists have long dominated the impoverished region. Much of their success comes from support by major landowners, who traditionally control the votes of the rural poor. Many voters also view environmentalism as an attempt to block economic growth and lock the Amazon into perennial backwardness. Slash-and-burn techniques used by ranchers and farmers have already destroyed about 8 percent of the 2-million-square-mile wilderness, according to government figures. In Amazonas, the area's largest state, incoming governor Gilberto Mestrinho favors widescale destruction of the rain forest to promote large mining and agricultural projects. The state's new senator, Amazonino Mendes, proposed handing out chain saws to settlers to speed the felling of the forest. In neighboring Roraima state, both gubernatorial finalists openly opposed federal plans to remove thousands of gold miners from the territory of the Yanomami Indians, the world's largest remaining primitive tribe. The miners illegally search for gold, diamonds and other minerals on Indian land. Armed clashes and imported diseases killed about 1,500 of the tribe's remaining 9,000 members in the past three years. The favorite in Roraima's gubernatorial race is Romero Juca, now on trial for illegally authorizing logging on Indian land when he was chief of the National Indian Foundation in the early 1980s. ``The elections in Roraima could spell the end for the Yanomami,'' Fleischer remarked, In Para state, the runoff pits anti-ecology candidates Jaber Barbalho and Sahid Xerfan. Para has been the site of repeated clashes between Indians and miners. Miners have dumped about 600 tons of mercury from gold prospecting into the Tapajos River. ``We have no preference in Para,'' Gabeira said. ``Neither possible winner will defend the Indians or the Amazon.'' Big farmers are blamed for most of the violence plaguing the region. More than 1,000 peasant activists were killed in land conflicts in the past decade. The Rev. Ricardo Resende of the Pastoral Land Commission said in a phone interview from Para state, ``The new governors are well known and most have never demonstrated any interest in protecting the region's poor. Small farmers will continue to be expelled from their land.'' His commission is linked with the Roman Catholic Church. Gabeira said the only bright spot was in Acre, home to thousands of rubber tappers, where Jorge Viana of the pro-environmentalist Workers Party won a spot in the second round. His strength is largely attributed to the legacy of world-renowned unionist and ecologist Chico Mendes, a Workers Party activist murdered in 1988. Mendes' alleged killers are going on trial Oct. 25, and the publicity could boost Viana's campaign. There was another note of encouragement to the rain forest's advocates Sunday contained in an article in the newspaper Jornal do Brasil. It reported that the area of the Amazon rain forest destroyed by fires in 1990 was down considerably from last year. Data compiled by Brazil's National Institute of Space Research showed overall destruction may be down by as much as 50 percent, the newspaper said. Institute President Marcio Barbosa was quoted as saying that the space satellite that monitors the Amazon has been crucial to efforts to prevent further damage.

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Expert Dies
DOC.TEXT: J. Murray Mitchell, 62, a retired senior research climatologist and meteorologist with the National Oceanic and Atmosphere Administration, has died of lymphoma. Mitchell was a leading authority on climatology and the study of long-term weather trends and the impact of climate change on populations. He was the among the scientists who warned for years about the potential impact of global warming on Earth's environment.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Sand Wears Out Helicopters, Provides Few Landmarks for Pilots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA3 sent Oct. 7.
DOC.TEXT: The sands of the Saudi desert are chewing through helicopter parts much faster than expected, causing problems for U.S. anti-tank Apaches and Cobras, Army officers say. The helicopters belong to the 24th Mechanized Division's air brigade of Fort Stewart, Ga., which holds some of the most forward positions of the growing U.S. force in northeastern Saudi Arabia. The helicopter crews have trained in California's Mojave Desert. But despite similrities in the terrain, the sands of the Mojave did not scour as the Saudi sand does, officers and maintenance personnel said. The 24th's helicopters include the high-tech AH-64A Apache and AH-1 Cobra gunships, OH-58 Kiowas used to scout enemy tank formations; UH-60 Blackhawk and UH-1 Huey transporters and those fitted for electronic warfare. Despite the maintenance burden, at least 70 percent of the aircraft are operational at any given moment, said the brigade commander, Col. Burt Tackaberry, 43, of Jacksonville, Fla. He said the rate had dipped into the 60 percent range when the brigade first moved into its desert camp 10 days ago. But he said it would not go that low again after flying hours were reduced. Defense Department ground rules prohibit mentioning exact numbers or locations. Tackaberry said the brigade does not have its full supplies of spare parts yet, but he was confident it could start fighting a war if necessary. The U.S. force is facing off Iraqi troops following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait. The colonel said the Apaches have so many backup systems - three radio systems, for example, and two types of night vision equipment - that the failure of one would not knock the helicopter out of combat. But desert sand is wearing out the surface of the rotary blades. Also, fine sand sucked into the hot engines can melt into glass that chips and ruts internal parts in the turbines. Sand clogs the starting valves and it gets between the twin panes of the windshield, reducing visibility. ``The sand is at work and so are we,'' said Warrant Officer Richard L. Paradis, 38, of Pooler, Ga., a member of one of the brigade's two maintenance teams. ``We go through a lot of main rotor blades, a lot of tail blades,'' he said. ``In the desert, we're using about five times as much.'' The main engines have to be pulled and cleaned after every 250 hours of flying time, something that does not happen under usual conditions. Staving off wear and tear on the machines requires all sorts of ingenuity. Coats of rubbery epoxy paint are to be added to the front edge rotary blades to slow the corrosion. The maintenance teams are experimenting with ways of keeping dust out of the engines, such as fitting the engines with the tough, flat scouring pads used in many kitchens. Navigation is also a problem. The crews who trained in the Mojave are having to learn from scratch how to navigate in the featureless terrain south of the border with occupied Kuwait. ``Occasionally you see a few dried up lake beds and camel herds,'' said Capt. Kelly Marunde, 30, head of air traffic control and the sole female company commander in the aviation brigade. ``But the herds move and the sand blows, so you can't really rely on anything being there the next day.''

DOC.HEAD: Austrian Elections: Leader Tries to Contain Right-of-center Opponent
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, a Socialist, is trying to stem the rising fortunes of a right-of-center opponent and the Green movement in national elections Sunday. The latest polls showed an unprecedented 23 percent of voters unsure which party they prefer, raising great uncertainty as Austrians began casting ballots at 7 a.m. The last voting stations close at 5 p.m. (noon EDT). Voter surveys indicate the most likely outcome is that the governing socialist-conservative coalition will remain in control of Parliament. The coalition consists of Vranitzky's Socialist Party and the conservative Austrian People's Party, which is led by Vice Chancellor Josef Riegler. However, the two major parties stand to lose seats to the right-of-center Freedom Party of populist Joerg Haider; and, to a lesser extent, the environmental Green Alternative Party. Haider, governor of the southern Carinthia province, has won considerable popularity for his often witty remarks. He has often resorted to abusive language in criticizing the leaders of the governing coalition and their policies. The 53-year-old chancellor has rejected any possibility of a coalition with Haider, who is accused by many Socialists of appealing to advocates of rightist policies. Some conservatives are considering the possibility of forming a right-of-center coalition with the Freedom Party. However, Riegler said he does not want to cooperate with Haider. In the 1986 elections, the Socialists gained 80 seats, the People's Party 77, the Freedom Party 18 and the Greens 8. On Sunday, a total of 5,628,913 people, including for the first time 21,232 Austrians living abroad, were registered to vote for the 183 parliamentary deputies. Haider said he hopes the Freedom Party wins between 25 and 30 seats at the expense of the two major parties. The Greens also want to double their seats. The tiny Communist Party and a few other small political parties have virtually no chance of gaining seats. The election campaign was generally lackluster, though marked by some name-calling. Major party leaders refrained from sharp attacks, possibly with a view toward maintaining the governing coalition. No single issue predominated. Candidates debated immigration and Austrian efforts to win membership in the European Community, the European nations working to integrate their economies.

DOC.HEAD: Ulysses Probes Zips Across Space, Astronauts Conduct Experiments
DOC.TEXT: The Ulysses probe sprinted through space Sunday on its five-year trip to study the sun, while the Discovery astronauts who dispatched the craft turned their attention to scientific experiments. Ulysses, an atomic-powered spacecraft released from the shuttle Saturday, was traveling about 34,130 mph, the fastest speed ever for a manmade object. ``It's outbound and doing well,'' flight director Gary Coen said. Discovery's five astronauts got up early Sunday morning to begin a day of experiments that included lighting a small controlled fire, growing plant roots and testing a system in which shuttle cameras are maneuvered by voice commands. Mission Control awakened the crew with a song written and performed by Boeing Aerospace & Electronics Co. employees as a tribute to the successful deployment of the probe, partially boosted into space by a Boeing-built rocket. ``Sailing along, sailing along, flying to explore the galaxy,'' the aerospace workers sang. No problems with the space shuttle were reported, Coen said. ``Everybody is real happy that things are going so smoothly,'' he said. Saturday was a banner-day for the space agency, which has suffered through months of frustrating problems with its space shuttles and the flawed Hubble Space Telescope. First, the Discovery thundered into space just 12 minutes behind schedule. A minor weather problem and a last-minute technical glitch caused the delay of the first shuttle launch in nearly six months. Six hours later, the crew deployed the Ulysses sun probe - the primary goal of the mission. After a roundabout journey, Ulysses is scheduled to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994, then curve over the north solar pole. The sun's poles cannot be seen from Earth and have never been examined closely by scientists. Discovery is scheduled to land Wednesday in the California desert. The mission wasn't affected by the shutdown of many federal agencies because funds for the mission already had been set aside, officials said. The shuttle commander is Richard N. Richards, and the other crew members are pilot Robert D. Cabana and mission specialists William M. Shepherd, Bruce Melnick and Thomas D. Akers.

DOC.HEAD: Johnston Overcomes Duke Challenge to Win Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Sen. J. Bennett Johnston overcame a strong challenge from white supremacist David Duke and won a fourth term in office without the need for a runoff. ``My friends, I am here to tell you tonight: We did it!'' Johnston shouted to supporters after Saturday's victory, which calmed the fears of Louisiana's political establishment, Democratic and Republican alike. In final, unofficial results, Johnston, a Democrat, had 749,552 votes or 54 percent and Duke, a Republican, had 605,681 votes or 44 percent. Two minor Democratic candidates divided the remainder: Nick Accardo had 21,709 votes and Larry Crowe had 14,472 votes. Duke's strong candidacy had rattled leaders of both parties, and prompted the endorsed Republican candidate, state Sen. Ben Bagert, to drop out of the race last week out of fear that he could force a runoff between Duke and Johnston. Duke, a state representative, is a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. Although he claims to have reformed since his Klan days, he has been successful in mainstream politics by preaching civil rights for white people and attacking affirmative action and the welfare system. Duke, appearing before supporters, refused to concede and said Johnston would not get the majority needed to avoid a runoff. He threatened a court fight over the issue of whether absentee ballots cast for Bagert before he dropped out should be counted. ``All I can tell you is that we have not yet begun to fight,'' Duke said. Also Saturday, Louisiana voters overwhelmingly approved a state lottery, and New Orleans moved closer to electing its first black congressman since Reconstruction. State Sen. William Jefferson and Marc Morial, the son of former Mayor Dutch Morial, headed a field of 12 for a Nov. 6 runoff in the 2nd District replace retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs, the only white House member to represent a majority black district.

DOC.HEAD: Son Saves Mother From Crocodile By Poking Its Eye
DOC.TEXT: A 14-foot-long crocodile attacked a woman and started carrying her away in its jaws, but her son rescued her by jumping on the reptile's back and poking it in the eye, police said Sunday. The woman, who was not identified, was attacked Saturday night while sleeping next to a creek in the Daly River Aboriginal reserve, about 120 miles south of Darwin in the Northern Territory. Ray Musgrave, Daly River police constable, said the woman's 30-year-old son jumped on top of the crocodile and poked it in the eye as it tried to retreat with his mother in its jaws. The crocodile then released the woman, police said. Musgrave said the pair had been sleeping in a mesh tent with the woman's husband and five other children. Officials said the woman was taken to a Darwin hospital, where she was in stable but critical condition.

DOC.HEAD: Hijacking of Soviet Flight Foiled by Crew, Passengers
DOC.TEXT: The crew and passengers of an Aeroflot plane overpowered a man who tried to hijack it Sunday to Sweden in the latest of a series of hijacking attempts in the Soviet Union, Tass reported. The man threatened to blow up the An-24 turboprop plane if it was not diverted to Stockholm, the Soviet news agency said. The plane was flying from Perm, a city in central Russia 840 miles east of Moscow, to Arkhangelsk, in the northwestern part of the country. As the plane was preparing to land in the city of Kotlas, about halfway to Arkhangelsk, the crew ``decided to take the risk, and with the help of the passengers, disarmed the hijacker,'' Tass reported. The man, identified only as Gavrilov, a 26-year-old unemployed resident of Perm, had no bomb, Tass said. Tass did not provide any other details about the incident, including how many people were aboard the plane and how the man was overpowered. An An-24 can seat about 45 people. On Friday, an unarmed Soviet man forced an Aeroflot airliner on a domestic flight to land in Finland, where he requested political asylum. The man, identified as Nikolai I. Selivanov, had threatened to blow up the plane if it did not go to Stockholm, but he was told there wasn't enough fuel and it landed in Helsinki instead. There have been more than a dozen hijackings or attempted hijackings of Aeroflot flights this year. Five of the flights were hijacked to Finland or Sweden. Four of the hijackers have been extradited to the Soviet Union, and one was granted political asylum in Sweden. Finnish aviation and police officials have requested negotiations with the Soviets to deter hijackers, but the Soviets have not answered the request. In addition, plainclothes police have been flying aboard some Aeroflot planes to deter possible hijackers.

DOC.SECOND: Souter: The More Things Change, the More He Stays the Same
DOC.TEXT: His presumed ideology has been condemned on all sides, his husekeeping has been derided and his neckties have been likened to dishrags, but David Souter's friends say he is a man content with himself who won't change when he joins the Supreme Court this week. ``Goodness no, that's like saying that Gibraltar could be changed by a rainstorm,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., who preceded Souter as state attorney general and sat behind him all through Senate confirmation hearings. ``David Souter's foundations and values have been built over 51 years,'' Rudman said. ``David hasn't changed at all and will not change at all.'' The 51-year-old ascetic bachelor's life has been turned upside down in the past few months as he went from a little-known regional jurist to one of the nation's nine most powerful judges. Liberals and conservatives alike have voiced suspicions that he'll vote against them on abortion, civil rights and other social issues. Journalists have scrutinized everything from his suits to how he'll cope with crime, noise and high real estate prices in the nation's capital. But friends say he ultimately will be the soft-spoken, even-tempered man he always has been whether he is in Weare, N.H., or Washington, where he moved this weekend to get ready to join the court Tuesday. ``He's in a constant whirl of change, but he will be himself wherever he is. ... He is satisfied with who he is,'' said Concord lawyer Tom Rath, Souter's deputy and successor as attorney general. Throughout a barrage of public and media scrutiny that began when President Bush nominated him to the court July 23, Souter remained polite, almost courtly, to anyone who begged a minute. ``No trouble at all,'' he told a apologetic reporter who called him at his Weare farmhouse - the phone number is still in the book - the day he returned from Senate Judiciary Committee hearings. ``That's David Souter,'' Rudman said. ``He is without a doubt one of the most self-effacing, gracious people I have ever met.'' But, Rath noted, ``I think there were moments when that sort of basic nature of him - good natured, unfailingly courteous - was tested.'' Some of those moments included an inventory of Souter's ancient kitchen appliances made by reporters peeking through his windows while he was in Washington meeting senators. Souter joked about it: ``When I think of all the things I should have left out if I'd known somebody was going to peek - but I'll never have that chance again.'' In reality, he was annoyed, Rudman and Rath said. ``He didn't like that and he felt people overstepped their bounds, but I think he understood that for a few weeks or months he'd have to endure it,'' Rudman said. Rath said friends tried to make sure that Souter's courtesy didn't allow people to take advantage of him. ``I got angry a couple of times, very angry the first Friday he got back and ... he went over to see his mother,'' said Rath, who acted as Souter's press agent and personal sentry after the nomination. Souter, he recalled, went in the back door of his mother's home in a Concord retirement community. Immediately, reporters converged on the front entrance. ``The man hadn't even seen his mother and four or five reporters were knocking on his door. I said, `Look, fellows, come over here and interview me.' '' Even well-wishing neighbors created some problems, although Souter and Rath said their support was appreciated. ``He told me the other day that he parked his car at the post office to mail a package and it took him 45 minutes to get from his car to the window,'' Rath said. ``People are warm and friendly and such, but it gets wearing.'' Everyone in Souter's circle are happy that the attents abating. ``I think there's a feeling of enormous relief,'' Rath said. ``This is a man who likes his work. And the fact that he hasn't been able to work for the last 2{ months has been hard.'' Once he goes back to work, he'll stay there, eschewing the Washington social scene that already has chosen him one of its most eligible bachelors, Rudman predicted. ``He will be here as he was in New Hampshire, essentially extraordinarily hard-working,'' he said. ``If anybody in this city thinks that those phonies who send him those power invitations will get their hands on him, they are in for one terrible disappointment,'' said Rudman, whose dislike for the social whirl is well known. ``As of Monday at 5 p.m.,'' when Souter will take the first of two oaths of office, Rudman said, ``he will essentially disappear as a person who is seen in the scene here in this city.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorcycle-Bound Thief Strikes For 21st Time
DOC.TEXT: A motorcycle-bound bandit robbed his 21st bank Sunday, again evading police pursuit to speed away with his loot. The thief has been operating in more than 20 Israeli towns, robbing banks of a total of about $150,000. He has left no clue and no description - just a fingerprint that draws a blank in the police computer. The thief, who has been nicknamed ``Bikerbank'' in Hebrew, always uses the same method. He strikes between 10 a.m. and noon, and robs the teller nearest to the bank door, firing one shot in the air from his .38 Smith and Wesson pistol. He is about six feet tall, wears cowboy or army boots, has blond hair and, according to some witnesses, a slight limp. He rides a Suzuki motorcycle. On Sunday morning, he struck at the Bank Hapoalim branch in Ramat Gan, near Tel Aviv. His loot was $2,500. Police erected roadblocks around the robbery area, closed a major highway leading to Tel Aviv for more than an hour and searched with helicopters. But their efforts were in vain.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iranian Envoy In Beirut To Finalize Waite's Release
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported Sunday that an Iranian envoy has arrived in Beirut to prepare for the release of Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite ``in the next few days.'' The report by the conservative ad-Diyar could not be confirmed. The paper is not known to have had special insight into the hostage issue. But the report came amid mounting speculation that one or more of the four Britons missing in Lebanon could be freed soon. Iran and Britain restored diplomatic relations on Sept. 27. On Saturday, Lebanon's leading newspaper, the independent an-Nahar daily, said that Waite and ``a number of foreign hostages'' were expected to be released this week. Arab sources in Damascus, Syria's capital, said Sunday that the Syrians are making strenuous efforts to free some of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk Sharaa is trying hard ``to resolve the issue but has been encountering unexpected obstacles.'' He did not elaborate, but noted that Sharaa is expected to meet soon with Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to discuss the issue. They met last week at the United Nations in New York. Speculation also has been fueled by expectations that Britain and Syria will soon restore relations. Britain broke off ties in October 1986 after Syrian intelligence was implicated in a plot to bomb an Israeli airliner at London's Heathrow airport. Ad-Diyar said the unidentified Iranian official flew into Beirut Saturday carrying an Algerian passport. ``Secret talks have been held in the last two months and resulted in agreement on the release operation as well as the final touches and details,'' the report said. It said the envoy was assigned to supervise the release, which would come ``in the next few days.'' In London, the British Foreign Office said there was nothing to the report and reiterated British policy that it will not negotiate to get hostages out. Britain and Iran restored diplomatic relations after a 19-month break triggered by the publication of British author Salman Rushdie's novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Many Moslems say the book blasphemes Islam. Ad-Diyar said Waite's release was expected to be ``the preface to releasing all British hostages in Lebanon.'' The other missing Britons are journalist John McCarthy, retired pilot Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. It said the agreement to release Waite involved a $10 million ``fee to the forces'' who kidnapped him. Waite, 51, disappeare Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel in Moslem west Beirut for a meeting with representatives of Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. The pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem faction is believed to hold American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. No group claims to have kidnapped Waite. But a former hostage, Irishman Brian Keenan, said after he was released by Shiite captors in August that Waite was held with him for a while. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani apparently has been seeking to free the hostages in his drive to improve relations with the West following the June 1989 death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. He has been opposed by radicals in his own government.

DOC.HEAD: Hunt Ends With No Sign of Beast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd pvs to CORRECT first reference to company.
DOC.TEXT: A two-day search for the Loch Ness monster ended Sunday with two blips on a radar screen but no evidence of the legendary beast. National oddsmakers William Hill Organization Ltd., which had offered 250,000 pounds ($477,500) for ``conclusive evidence'' of Nessie, kept its reward but paid 1,500 pounds ($2,850) to a Scottish company for the best search method. Oceanscan, which supplies underwater sonar equipment for the North Sea oil industry, used underwater radar and registered an unidentified object up to 26 feet long. ``The object which showed up yesterday registered as two blips on the sonar screen but it moved out of range very quickly. We can't be sure what it was,'' said Andy Gray, Oceanscan's managing director. The three other hunting parties participating in the first major search in three years came up empty. But Daniel Isted, a 25-year-old London editor of a corporate in-house magazine, managed to catch himself a bride. His girlfriend, Dee Smith, accepted his proposal along the shore of Loch Ness. The lake is 754 feet deep, 23 miles long and a mile wide. William Hill is offering 100-1 odds that Nessie's existence will not be authenticated within a year.

DOC.HEAD: Books Ahoy! Librarians Ship Out Supplies to Gulf
With AM-Gulf-Life In Exile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As U.S. forces were building up in the Persian Gulf, the cruiser USS LaSalle sent an urgent message to Saufley Field in the Florida Panhandle. The flagship of Operation Desert Shield needed books. The LaSalle wanted information on Middle East culture, customs, history and even artists and authors, recalled library technician Dot Bibee. The Navy's four-woman Library Services Division had a shipment on its way in 24 hours, she said. ``Whenever we hear from a ship, that's when we jump,'' said division head Marge Homeyard. Titles sent to the LaSalle included ``Saddam's Iraq,'' ``Iraq in Pictures,'' ``Women at Work in the Gulf'' and ``Images of Bahrain.'' This is a busy time for military librarians, who are jumping to meet a huge demand for books for U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf. Not all requests are as specialized as the LaSalle's. The military waiting game in the Gulf has left soldiers and sailors with plenty of time to read, and their tastes take in the full range of a library's shelves. Among the most popular are techno-military yarns by Tom Clanc, whose works include ``Hunt for Red October'' and ``Red Storm Rising,'' and Stephen Coonts, author of ``Flight of the Intruder.'' Horror stories by Stephen King and westerns by Louis L'Amour also are popular, and the increasing number of women in the military has created a demand for novels by romance authors such as Danielle Steel. Paperbacks are preferred. ``They are the go-anywhere type of books,'' said Willie Quinley, another library technician. ``Stash one in your back pocket and you can go to the john with it. It's kind of hard to do that with a hardback.'' Shipboard libraries even include children's books. Military parents can record themselves reading the stories and send the tapes to their children. Shipments for the Persian Gulf are screened to avoid sending books that might offend the conservative host countries by being too violent or sexy, including covers with pictures of scantily clad women. ``To the extent possible, we are sanitizing,'' Homeyard said. That, however, was not possible for ships that sailed into the region with existing libraries. ``To some extent, we have our fingers crossed we are not going to have an international incident over a library book,'' Homeyard said. The library supply operation is part of the Naval Education and Training Program Management Support Activity at Saufley, a former flight training auxiliary base a few miles from the Pensacola Naval Air Station. In addition to ships, the agency supplies books to 147 Navy and 27 Marine Corps shore libraries and 343 units at remote sites. The Air Force and Army have similar library functions at Randolph Air Force Base, Texas, and Arlington, Va. The services have been working together to supply books to their troops in the Persian Gulf. Navy library activities in the Gulf are headed by Lt. Cmdr. Gary Simons, who like most library officers is a chaplain. Simons sent a message Sept. 23 from Bahrain to report that Desert Shield sailors were enjoying their books but that his supply was exhausted. His message, like the one from the LaSalle, received immediate attention. The division scrounged through its own stash of mostly review books to ship 23 boxes. It arranged for 15 more from the aircraft carrier USS Kitty Hawk, which is being overhauled in Philadelphia and is now overstocked with books, Quinley said. An illustrated book on body building, male and female, was deleted. ``Not only were (the models) scantily clad, it had Venus, the statue of the naked lady, and a male (statue) also,'' Quinley said. ``It may be art, but they might not understand if it got in the wrong hands.''

DOC.HEAD: Members who used AM-Southwest Lawsuit, which moved as a0768 on Oct. 5 under a Dallas dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported incorrectly that a federal lawsuit against Southwest Airlines alleged the company had failed to hire a pilot older than 45 since 1987. The lawsuit alleges that Southwest has failed to hire enough pilots older than 45 during that time. The incorrect information was contained in a press release from the U.S. Equal Opportunity Commission. An EEOC spokeswoman on Saturday said the release was in error. She agreed with a Southwest statement contained in the original story that the airline had hired 39 pilots older than 45 since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Gov't Conducts Affairs Of State - From A Luxury Hotel
DOC.TEXT: The royal government of Kuwait, shielded by Saudi guards and served by an army of room service waiters, meets regularly on the affairs of a state its Iraqi occupiers claim no longer exists. Its Cabinet room is a plushly appointed suite in the Al Hada Sheraton, a mountaintop resort that is temporarily out of business as a hotel. The government's records and reports - the apparatus of displaced rulers struggling to keep their emirate together from a distance - are stuffed in dressers, back rooms and broom closets. In stark contrast to the foreign refugees from Kuwait stranded in Jordanian desert camps, Kuwaiti officials pad about in cooled air on thick carpets, soothed by plaintive Arabic melodies from speakers. On a recent afternoon, a Lebanese merchant lugged in a suitcase full of gold Swiss watches for idle customers. It was clear that time hung heavily on their hands. Men in snowy white Arab headgear and shirt-gowns float about the quiet corridors. In between flurries of activity, they sip coffee, dine elaborately or nap at length. About 300 Kuwaiti officials and family members live in bungalows on the grounds. Unruly children scamper about colorful gardens inside high fences. Offices and staff rooms are in the seven-story main building. Hotel shops are closed, except for the Bangladeshi scent man in the lobby. In flasks out of ``1001 Nights,'' he sells 500 aromas, along with fragrant resins, exotic wood chips and Paris perfumes. ``Try this,'' he said, slashing a browser's hand with pungent oil. ``It's called `Queen of the Night.''' Not even Saudi police cars get past the barrier at the front gate without a coded pass and a rigorous check. Authorized visitors surrender their passports for a green badge which, in turn, is traded for a pink badge. A thorough but good-natured security chief named Mohammed, referring to the Iraqi invasion, jokes with foreigners that they will be free to leave whenever they wish. Once inside, visitors are showered in courtly hospitality and prodded for news. During a recent interview, Sheik Saad al Abdullah al Salim al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti crown prince and prime minister, punctuated a reporter's queries with questions of his own. Seven neat stacks of regional newspapers lay at anyone's disposal in the lobby. But most information filters in slowly from the dwindling number of Kuwaiti refugees who make it out of their homeland. Few officials are anxious to be named in news dispatches for fear their relatives back home might suffer. Pointing to a colleague, one Kuwaiti said: ``He just found out three days ago that his brother was carried off to Baghdad to work as a technician for the Iraqi Air Force. I don't think he wants to talk about it.'' The Information Ministry is on the first floor, obvious from the stacks of poster-sized photos in the hallway. One is the celebrated scene of Saddam Hussein patting a visibly uncomfortable British hostage boy. Next to it, a poster shows Adolf Hitler caressing a pleased German youth of similar age. Nearby, several dozen different photos of Iraqi atrocities and damage to Kuwait are piled high on a counter. But there are few takers. After a month in the hotel, spirits are still high, assured Hamad Jabal al-Sabah, a ministry official and son of the prime minister. ``Maybe we'll be back in Kuwait by the end of the month.'' But some others seemed dubious. More than one Kuwaiti has noted the irony in the housing advertisement displayed in each of the hotel's elevators: ``You'll love the life at the Sheraton.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Duke Concedes Johnston Won Re-Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: will be incorporated in the AM-Louisiana Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke conceded Sunday that U.S. Sen. Bennett Johnston was re-elected in the Louisiana open primary and said he would not challenge the outcome in court. ``I'm here to concede the election to Bennett Johnston, but I'm not going to concede or relinquish my commitment to the principle of equal rights for every American,'' Duke, a first-term state representative, told a news conference. In complete but unofficial returns form the Saturday voting, Johnston had 54 percent of the vote and Duke 44 percent. As the vote was counted, Duke had said he would ask for a court order to challenge absentee votes that were cast before Ben Bagert, the official Republican candidate, dropped out on Thursday. Under state law, any votes for Bagert were not counted after he dropped out. Though he backed off on the idea of filing his own challenge, Duke said Sunday that his organization would support any individual who wanted to pursue the matter in court. ``We'll help people who feel their right to vote has been abrogated,'' he said. ``We'll help them pursue that if they so desire, but I'm trying to do - as Bennett Johnston said - and kind of heal at this point. ``I want to see the state together. I want people to get behind Bennett but I want them to make sure that Bennett pursues policies that are good for the people of Louisiana.'' Bagert dropped out and encouraged his backers to vote for Bennett after polls showed him running a distant third in the race. Several Republicans in the U.S. Senate also took the unusual step of backing Democrat Johnston in the primary, saying they didn't want the former Klansman to force Johnston into a runoff. Under the state's open primary, candidates all run in one primary, regardless of party. If no one candidate gains a majority of the votes, a runoff is held among the top two vote-getters.

DOC.HEAD: Simon Runs Into Integrity Questions, But Leaves Challenger Far Behind
With AM-Louisiana Primary Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Lynn Martin has portrayed Illinois Sen. Paul Simon as a tax-happy liberal and a string-pulling Washington insider, but neither approach appears to have helped much in her race to unseat him. Martin was trailing Simon by a 2-to-1 margin in a recent poll and her underfinanced campaign hasn't run television ads for more than a week. With the Nov. 6 election closing in, she has been unable to catch Simon even though the former crime-fighting newspaper editor has been tarnished by questions about his conduct in two cases: - That he called a San Francisco bank urging officials to negotiate a settlement with Michael Ballis, a developer and Simon fund-raiser involved in a dispute over a construction project. - And that he wrote to the Higher Education Assistance Foundation on behalf of a now-closed cooking school, whose owner then made two $1,000 in-kind contributions to Simon's campaign. HEAF, a guarantor of the government-backed loans, was asked to lower the monthly payments. On his intervention with the bank, Simon, 61, said he was merely helping a constituent and trying to avoid court costs. Martin countered with a TV advertisement that used the word ``fix.'' Simon accepted blame for the cooking school incident, saying his staff used bad judgment in dealing with the cooking school operator. Martin stoked the coals, saying ``How many more cases like this are there?'' Still, a poll released last week showed Simon favored by 60 percent of those surveyed, with Martin supported by 31 percent. The Sept. 23-Oct. 1 survey for WLS-TV in Chicago showed 9 percent undecided, and had a 3 percentage point margin of error. Political analyst Charles Cook says Martin ``needs substantially more positive advertising than has been done thus far and will still have to go back on negative (ads) in a big way again.'' ``Whether she has the money to do both in sufficient quantities is a very good question,'' Cook said. As of June 30, Simon had raised $5.7 million, compared with $3.4 million for Martin. The next campaign finance reports are due next week. When she announced her candidacy last year, Martin, 50, tried to paint Simon as a tax-loving liberal who had abandoned the state to run for president less than three years into his first term. He missed nearly 60 percent of Senate votes in 1987 while he sought the Democratic nomination. ``Illinois deserves better,'' she said. With President Bush and congressional leaders embracing higher taxes, she emphasizes her anti-tax stance on the campaign trail. ``Muggers in pinstriped suits,'' she said of those pushing a $500 billion tax-and-spending cuts proposal that was defeated by the House last week. ``They're back at your pocketbook again.'' But it has been rough going for Martin. Simon has the support of most women's groups, and those that are not in his camp are staying on the sideline instead of aiding Martin. Both candidates back abortion rights. Martin's integrity also is under attack. Simon's campaign said she should return nearly $60,000 in campaign contributions and speaking fees to Sundstrand Corp. and its executives. Sundstrand, which is in Martin's northwest Illinois district, pleaded guilty to defrauding the Pentagon in 1988 and was barred from government defense work for a few months. Martin once told an interviewer that she's ``to the right of Atilla the Hun'' when it comes to government spending. Simon's camp has used that against her, finding votes and public comments to portray the former teacher as a foe of schools. A Simon TV ad mentions Martin's votes against Medicare. A member of four Senate committees, Simon has promoted his sponsorship of the government's literacy program and his work on behalf of college students who need federal aid.

DOC.HEAD: With New Chinese Tanks, Khmer Rouge Prepare To Attack Key Region
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer recently spent 10 days traveling through guerrilla-held territory in northwestern Cambodia where the Communist Khmer Rouge are preparing for a major offensive.

Bolstered by their first shipments of Chinese tanks, Khmer Rouge guerrillas are preparing a major attack to seize an area considered Cambodia's most important cultural and historic region. After making major gains in rural areas in the past year, the Khmer Rouge now are shifting to conventional military tactics to seize cities and key economic regions, Western military analysts say. The rebels recently took the key government artillery base at Sre Noi, and now say they are preparing to attack Bantei Srei, the last major government position defending the provincial capital of Siem Reap and the nearby Angkor Wat temples, the symbol of Cambodian civilization. The rebels have massed tanks, heavy guns and troops to attack government defenses in this northwestern province, according to field commanders and Khmer Rouge fighters interviewed in the guerrilla zone. A recent 10-day, 190-mile trek through guerrilla-held area near Angkor Wat showed the rebels had overrun important positions and moved freely through villages less than an hour's drive from the Siem Reap provincial capital. ``We were ordered to attack Bantei Srei this month and then we will attack Siem Reap,''said Bong Thieun, a young Khmer Rouge soldier interviewed at Sre Noi. Khmer Rouge bulldozers and chainsaws are carving tank and truck roads through the jungles toward Angkor Wat. ``What we see happening in Siem Reap is alarming,'' said a Western military intelligence analyst. ``They are using a strategy different from anywhere else. It looks like a real move to take Siem Reap.'' Analysts said the capture of Siem Reap and Angkor Wat would be a major psychological victory. Thai and Western sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said China's secret delivery of 24 tanks is the first such shipment ever to the guerrillas. Dozens of the Communist rebels have returned to the jungles from China, where they were trained to operate tanks, they said. The sources said 12 tanks are at the Khmer Rouge-controlled district capital of Andung Veng, the staging area for the offensive against Siem Reap. The other 12 !s near the Khmer Rouge-held town of Pailin in western Battambang province. The guerrillas also have received scores of Chinese jeeps, transport trucks, and heavy weapons. The Khmer Rouge has relied on Chinese arms in the nearly 12-year-old war against the Vietnamese-installed government armed by the Soviet Union. Hundreds of thousands of people died from starvation, execution and disease during the Khmer Rouge's fanatical Communist rule from 1975 until Vietnam invaded in late 9)8. Areas of the country's north are under the control of former monarch Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whose guerrillas are allied with the Khmer Rouge and a third rebel group.
