Sihanouk has wide support among peasants, and several thousand of his troops move freely through scores of isolated rural villages. They are welcomed by many villagers fearful of the Khmer Rouge and deeply suspicious of Vietnam's influence over Prime Minister Hun Sen's government in Phnom Penh. But Sihanouk commanders say they cannot compete for territory with the Khmer Rouge, who have stockpiles of ammunition to fight for several years if China were to cut them off. ``The Khmer Rouge have lots of weapons, but few supporters,'' said Sihanouk commander Gen. Kien Van, at his jungle headquarters less than 20 miles from Angkor Wat. ``We have lots of supporters but few weapons. So the Khmer Rouge get stronger and the non-Communists get weaker.'' The United States and European countries recently decreased their support for the non-Communist guerrillas because they feared that it would help the Khmer Rouge return to power. ``We are doing our best to provide a democratic alternative to the Cambodian people, but we are weak,'' said Prince Norodom Ranariddh, Sihanouk's son and the commander in chief of his army. ``The West has decided not to support us, so there remains only two major forces in Cambodia - the Khmer Rouge and Hun Sen,'' he said. ``I have to say very frankly, and Washington will criticize me again - that against Siem Reap the Khmer Rouge will be the major attacking forces and the Khmer Rouge will use tanks and heavy artillery. ``They have cut the government supply roads and built a sophisticated resupply system,'' he said. Gen. Kien Van said the Khmer Rouge had promised 2,000 troops to attack Siem Reap. ``We will have seized Angkor Wat and Siem Reap by January at the latest,'' he said. The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council - Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States - agreed to a new peace plan for Cambodia in late August. But talks on the plan among the Cambodian factions broke down in Bangkok last month. After the failure of the Bangkok talks, Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan said the next talks should be held on the KhmerJSuge-controlled Khulen Mountain, north of Siem Reap city.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Refugees Arrive At Saudi Border
With AM-Gulf-Life In Exile, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Several hundred Kuwaiti refugees arrived at this border crossing Sunday, part of a growing exodus as Iraq again relaxed its restrictions on Kuwaitis leaving the occupied emirate. The border opened Friday following intensified night searches in Kuwait City, according to refugees. The searches prompted many of them to leave out of fear. Iraqi troops were confiscating all identification papers in Kuwait, the refugees reported. That raised Saudi fears that the Iraqis were planning to attempt to infiltrate agents into the kingdom, where a U.S.-led multinational force has gathered to confront Saddam Hussein's troops in Kuwait. The new refugee influx is the largest since mid-September, when 7,000 Kuwaitis poured through in a three-day frenzy. Iraq's motive in opening the border point was unclear. But those crossing said they suspected Baghdad was allowing people to leave for several reasons, including its program of turning the city into an armed camp, isolating the resistance movement and resettling Iraqis in Kuwait. About 1,000 people have arrived since Friday, most lacking any identification, border officials said. Up to 700 people, most of them women and children, were camped inside the border crossing awaiting confirmation of their identities by Saudi officials and the Saudi-based Kuwaiti government-in-exile. Saudi Arabia has sharply increased security at the Khafji crossing, and reporters are not allowed to circulate there. There are an estimated 300,000 Kuwaiti refugees in the Saudi kingdom and neighboring Persian Gulf states out of a pre-invasion native population of 600,000. Those arriving said Iraqi troops at the border were grabbing some men under age 40 and taking bribes to allow others to cross. Sara Ismail Ibrahim, who fled with nine members of her family, said two men, aged 21 and 22, were taken out of their car while trying to cross the border and were not seen again. Refugees claim young men are being sent back for Iraqi military service. The similar seizure of young men at the border had dried up the flow of refugees in September. One young man who swore at the Iraqi soldiers was shot at a checkpoint before the border earlier this week, said a Saudi who had been in close contact with arriving refugees. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. One group of six young Kuwaiti men said Sunday that they escaped across the desert because they feared they would be seized on the road. They said Iraqi soldiers had fired on their car. The men were later brought to the border for processing. The border opening was announced via the Iraqi-controlled media in occupied Kuwait, refugees said. Iraqi troops have been allowing only about 30 cars an hour to leave in the morning and midafternoon only. Issa el-Nasrallah, a Health Ministry employee who fled with his wife and four children, said that many people in Kuwait thought Iraq was preparing for combat there soon. ``They also want to isolate the resistance to have everyone but them leave. They're trying to force people out,'' he said. Nasrallah said acts of resistance had stopped in Kuwait City since the Iraqis began killing anyone suspected of belonging to the resistance, many in front of their families. The refugees said Iraqi authorities had announced that everyone has to have identification cards issued in Baghdad, effectively changing them all into Iraqi citizens. Several hundred Westerners are still believed to be hiding in Kuwait, fearful of being taken to Iraq for use as human shields at military and other strategic installations. ``Everybody's scared there. They don't know when the Iraqis will come in the house and kill them,'' said Yusuf al-Ali, 25, a Kuwaiti Airways pilot.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nation's Anniversary Passes Quietly
DOC.TEXT: East Germany would have been 41 years old on Sunday, but few people found a reason to mark the birth of a nation that no longer exists. The once-hallowed anniversary passed quietly with no lavish parades, no mass protests for democracy and, most significantly, no East Germany. The former Communist nation closed out its history Wednesday by acceding to West Germany. Lothar de Maiziere, the nation's first and last freely elected leader, said Sunday was ``not a day of forced marches and ordered jubiliation, but simply the first Sunday of a united Germany. ``We have achieved freedom and democracy,'' the former prime minister said in a statement. ``We will protect these as precious commodities.'' The Soviet Union formed the German Democratic Republic on Oct. 7, 1949 from the rubble of the Nazi empire and installed a Stalinist government. For 40 years, the anniversary was a national holiday marked by celebrations and parades that paid tribute to the nation's history and its Communist system. Last year, however, it became a flashpoint for the revolt that toppled the old regime and eventually opened the door to unification. The protests that had been gathering steam in the weeks previous were given new impetus when Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited the country and told East German leader Erich Honecker to institute reforms. ``Life punishes whoever comes late,'' he told Honecker. Thousands protested on the date last year, some shouting ``Gorby, help us!'' Less than two weeks later Honecker was ousted. A caretaker Communist government opened the Berlin Wall and promised free elections. De Maiziere's party was elected on a pro-unity platform, and East Germany's fate was sealed. One of the few vestiges of the past was in view Sunday, as some of the activists who helped lead the democratic revolt kept up their vigil outside the former headquarters of the Communist secret police in Berlin. The activists are trying to keep officials from the West from gaining control of the secret dossiers on 6 million people. They say the files should remain on what was once East German land and be made available to the public. Officials confirmed Saturday that West German investigators have begun examining the files to gather evidence to bring former secret police leaders to trial. But there was little else reminiscent of the past. The vast parking lot in front of the Palace of the Republic, once the seat of the former Communist Parliament, was turned over to an automobile show that charged passers-by $3.10 to enter. At the former Communist-run Old Museum, the ``National Gallery of the GDR'' remained intact, devoted to paintings and sculpture rendered by approved artists of the old government. Few people wandered past the stark artwork that paid homage to victims of Nazi fascism and workers. Most crowded into the remodeled sections devoted to Western artists such as Picasso, Warhol and Lichtenstein. There were still pockets of pity for the old country, however. ``I think it's tragic that we no longer have autonomy on this anniversary,'' said Susanne Meyl, 19, who sells books and catalogues of the museum's artwork. Ms. Meyl, one of the relatively few remaining members of the former Communist youth group, the Free German Youth, said the organization planned a memorial to the end of East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Local PTA Chapter Defects When National Group Endorses Gun Control
With AM-Hunting Death, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The right to bear arms is sacred in this rural Ozarks community of 600, so when the national Parent-Teacher Association came out in favor of gun control, the local PTA chapter dropped out. ``We don't want them using our money to support gun control. They take away our guns, what's next? Our kitchen knives?'' asked Judy Perryman, president of the Conway PTA. Guns are a way of life here. Hunters go afield after deer, doves, turkey and squirrels. Gun racks hanging in pickup trucks are a common site at the Dari-Serv, the town's lone restaurant. ``I would say 90 percent of the people here have guns in their homes,'' Mrs. Perryman said. Her husband, Dave, is a trapper and hunter, and their 11-year-old son, Davey, enjoys target shooting under his father's supervision. ``My husband and the other men here follow the rules,'' she said. ``Gun control is not for the law-abiding, it's for the lawless.'' When it dropped out last month, Conway apparently was the first PTA chapter in the nation to quit the national association because of its stance on gun control. The vote for succession was ``unanimous, about 100 to nothing,'' Mrs. Perryman said. They will instead form their own parent-teacher group, as yet unnamed, she said. Kathy Russell, a spokeswoman at the PTA's national headquarters in Chicago, said chapters rarely quit the 6.8-million-member association, which was founded in 1897. ``A few drop out because they feel dues are too high, but this is the first I've heard of anyone pulling out because of the gun control issue,'' she said. What got the 127 members of the Conway PTA riled was the resolution passed by the 100-member national PTA board of directors at the association's annual meeting in June. Noting that one of every 10 childhood deaths in the United States in 1987 was caused by a gun, the board, made up of PTA members from each state, endorsed the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act. The proposed legislation, named for James Brady, the former presidential news secretary who was seriously wounded in an assassination attempt on President Reagan in 1981, would require a seven-day waiting period and background check prior to the sale of firearms. The board also called for a ban on military-style, semi-automatic assault weapons. ``The PTA is not attempting to prevent law-abiding citizens from owning guns,'' the resolution said. ``We want to assure that firearms aren't easily available to minors, the mentally ill, drug addicts, illegal aliens or convicted criminals.'' Ms. Russell said the resolution, one of about a dozen approved by the board, was not meant to imply that every local PTA chapter should work to enact gun-control legislation. ``Just because it's a resolution with the national PTA doesn't mean we require each of the local units to agree with the position,'' she said. ``Basically, it's a consensus of the national membership and gives us an official position.'' School Superintendent Larry Ament said he's not surprised parents in Conway, a dairy-farming community about 30 miles east of Springfield, got stirred up over the issue. All but 25 cents of the $1.50 annual dues paid by each member of the Conway PTA went to the state and national PTA. Many parents didn't think they were getting their money's worth and favored putting the money toward local projects, Ament said. Meanwhile, Conway's PTA records, dating to 1935, were donated to a library. ``Maybe we're making a major mistake in doing this,'' Mrs. Perryman said. ``But we had to do something. There are better ways of educating parents and teachers than standing up for gun control.''

DOC.HEAD: Hunter Being Tried for Killing Woman He Mistook for Deer
LaserPhoto AD1
DOC.TEXT: Karen Wood had just moved to Maine with her husband and year-old twin girls when she walked behind her suburban home on a fall afternoon two years ago. Donald Rogerson, the manager of a supermarket produce department, was hunting in the woods behind Mrs. Wood's home that day, Nov. 15, 1988. Thinking he saw a deer, Rogerson fired his rifle. Mrs. Wood was hit in the chest and died. A grand jury cleared Rogerson, but a second grand jury later indicted him on a manslaughter charge. He goes on trial Tuesday in Penobscot County Superior Court in Bangor. Rogerson has pleaded innocent. His lawyer, Lewis Vafiades, said he will argue the shooting was an accident. The case triggered a fierce public debate over hunting in a state where 216,476 people bought hunting licenses last year and 30,260 deer were killed. It also revealed tensions between longtime residents and newcomers. The death of Mrs. Wood, 37, ``polarized the public on the issue of hunting,'' pitting non-hunters against hunters, said William J. Vail, commissioner of the state Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife. ``The fact that there was no immediate criminal charge in the case led some people to say, `Well, you can shoot a moose in Maine illegally and get fined up to $1,000, but if you shoot a human being nothing happens.' ``So it became a very emotional issue.It went way beyond the issue of should we hunt or not?'' Mrs. Wood's husband, Kevin, complained that ``the real issue has been distorted.'' ``This is not a hunters vs. non-hunters issue. It is a matter of (Rogerson) accepting responsibility for his actions,'' Wood said in an interview published Sunday in the Quad City Times in Davenport, Iowa. He now lives in Bettendorf, Iowa. Hunting accidents have not been unusual in Maine. In 1952, for instance, 19 people were killed in hunting accidents. But the number of deaths dropped sharply over the last two decades even as the number of hunters swelled. State officials credit hunter safety programs. Since 1973, all hunters have been required to wear fluorescent orange vests, and all new hunters applying for licenses have been required since 1986 to take a hunting safety course. In 1988, one person was killed in a hunting accident - Mrs. Wood. She had moved to Maine from Iowa four months earlier with her infant daughters, Lindsay and Laura, and her husband, who's a child psychologist. The family lived in the Bangor suburb of Hermon. Mrs. Wood was standing behind her home - 130 feet from her back door by some accounts, well within the area where hunting is banned under safety laws - when she was shot. Rogerson, who works at a local Shop N' Save supermarket, was arrested that evening and charged with manslaughter. But the charge was dropped the next month after a grand jury concluded his actions were neither criminally negligent nor criminally reckless. The finding triggered a flood of letters to newspapers. Some writers called for more stringent laws to replace the current statute prohibiting the use of firearms within 300 feet of an occupied residence. The Legislature rejected the suggestion. Other writers said Wood should have worn bright clothing because it was deer season. Some critics even suggested she was at fault for wearing white mittens, contending they could have been mistaken for the underside of a deer's tail. Some letters hinted that because she was ``from away'' - a term used to describe people from other states - she was ignorant of Maine's hunting practices and traditions. The state attorney general's office reopened the case after a television station reported that a nephew of Rogerson's lawyer had served on the first grand jury. The second grand jury indicted Rogerson in December. Rogerson, who is married and has three children, faces up to 20 years in prison if he is convicted. Vafiades would not allow his client to be interviewed. But Vafiades said Rogerson ``feels he is the target because of the circumstances of this case.'' Wood moved from Maine shortly after the first grand jury cleared Rogerson, and now lives in Iowa with his daughters, who are about to celebrate their third birthday. He said he doesn't have high hopes for a conviction. ``Part of the community has already voiced strong support for the man who killed my wife,'' he said. Vafiades said Rogerson has not hunted since that November day two years ago. As part of the settlement of a wrongful death suit filed by Woods, Rogerson agreed not to seek a new hunting license, Vafiades said. ``He just has no desire for it,'' the lawyer said. ``I doubt if he'll ever hunt again. It's still a very emotional thing for him.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Katharine Hepburn once said she wouldn't give ``a nickel'' for a watercolor she once painted of Beverly Hills while staying at John Barrymore's house. But when she donated the painting to a wildlife group to help it raise money in an auction, the group had a much higher price in mind. Hepburn's watercolor brought the highest bid during Saturday night's North American Wildlife Association's benefit - $5,000. But it was nowhere near the minimum price of $75,000 set in advance by the group, said Steven Sosensky, the association's attorney and chairman of the auction. About 160 people turned out at the Park Plaza Hotel for the auction to help the association's 24-hour wildlife rescue service in Connecticut. Hepburn painted the work while staying at Barrymore's home overlooking Beverly Hills and the Pacific Ocean. The 16-inch by 20-inch work is in an impressionistic style and is signed in the lower left corner, but not dated. She guessed she painted it in the 1960s. ``I do hope i will bring a price, although I wouldn't give you a nickel for it,'' she said in July when she donated the painting to the association. Other celebrity items donated included autographed photos and books from Bob Hope, Shirley MacLaine and Barbra Streisand, which went for between $20 and $150 each. Sosensky said the association had hoped to raise $150,000, but he believed the auction brought in less than $20,000. The association may try to auction off Hepburn's work on the West Coast, where they hoped for higher bids, Sosensky said. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer Waylon Jennings figured a joint concert might settle a dispute between a folk group named the Highwaymen and the group of country stars who use the same name. He was right. The country group Highwaymen - which includes Jennings, Willie Nelson, Johnny Cash and Kris Kristofferson - asked the folk group the Highwaymen to open a show for them. The folk group, whose members still perform occasionally and sell records as an oldies act, had sued the country group for using the same name. Jennings thought a joint concert would give the folk group a chance to play before a big crowd, promote their music and get paid for it. After the folk Highwaymen opened for the country Highwaymen on Monday night at the Universal Amphitheatre in Universal City, Calif., the folk group dropped its lawsuit, said Jennings' publicist. --- MANILA, Philippines (AP) - President Corazon Aquino's 19-year-old daughter fell from a stage Sunday as she was about to sing and dance during a live television show. Kristine Bernadette ``Kris'' Aquino was rushed to a hospital, but doctors said she suffered no serious injuries. Producer German Moreno said Miss Aquino missed the steps of a makeshift platform while preparing for a dance routine. She fell and disappeared beneath the 5-foot stage in front of a national television audience and viewers at the Araneta Coliseum in suburban Quezon city, where the show is produced. The incident caused panic as presidential guards and production staff rushed to pull Miss Aquino out from the hole. ``Accidents always happen,'' Moreno said on television. ``We did not expect that it would happen to her. I would like to apologize.'' At the end of the show, Moreno announced that Miss Aquino, a fledgling but highly paid actress, was in good condition except for pain in her legs. --- WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. (AP) - Actor Adam Rich, who played the youngest sibling on television's ``Eight is Enough,'' was accused of driving under the influence of alcohol, authorities said. Rich, 21, was arrested about 1 a.m. Saturday after sheriff's deputies spotted him making an illegal U-turn and driving erratically along Sunset Boulevard, said Lt. Lee Jordan. Tests revealed his blood alcohol level was .18 percent, more than twice the legal limit of .08 percent, Jordan said. Rich was cited and released Saturday. He must attend an Oct. 31 hearing at Beverly Hills Municipal Court to face the misdemeanor count, Jordan said. Rich entered the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage in July 1988 to kick a cocaine habit. At that time, his manager Jeff Ballard said the young actor was ``determined to straighten out his life.'' Rich starred as the pudgy moppet whose antics amused TV audiences in the comedy-drama series ``Eight is Enough'' that ran on ABC from 1977 to 1981. --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Sylvia Chase, who spent the past 4{ years anchoring the news for a local television station, says dramatic world events have lured her back to work at a network news program. Chase, who's joining ABC television's ``Prime Time'' team le by Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer, said the massacre in China's Tiananmen Square first sparked her professional fires. ``I had an almost physical yearning to go to China,'' says Chase, who was on vacation in Paris at the time. ``Then Eastern Europe started to unravel. The Berlin Wall came down. Renunification was on the way. ``These were all places where I had traveled, places I knew something about. The world was suddenly a different place.'' Chase went from ABC's ``20-20'' investigative reporting team to San Francisco's KRON in 1986. At 52, she said her age also was a factor in her decision to return to the network - older women such as Barbara Walters, Lesley Stahl and even Connie Chung and Diane Sawyer seem to last longer at the networks than on local stations. ``I'd say it was an important factor,'' Chase said in a recent interview. ``Not only is the world more interesting, but there's probably more future in going back to network.''

DOC.HEAD: Jurors: Mapplethorpe Photos May Be Lewd, But They're Art
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 6th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who acquitted an art gallery and its director of obscenity charges say that although they personally found some of Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs to be lewd and distasteful, all agreed they are serious works of art. ``The pictures were not pretty. No doubt about it,'' juror James Jones told The Cincinnati Enquirer in a story published Sunday. ``But, as it was brought up in the trial, to be art it doesn't have to be pretty.'' The jury deliberated two hours Friday before clearing Dennis Barrie and the Contemporary Arts Center of misdemeanor pandering obscenity and child-nudity charges in the first case of its kind against an art institution. Three jurors interviewed by the newspaper said they were surprised by the swift verdict. On both charges, the first jury vote was 7-1 in favor of acquittal. They did not say who voted to convict. ``We felt that the prosecution did not prove its case,'' said Jones, a warehouse manager. Five of the pictures in the 175-picture exhibition, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment,'' depict sexually explicit acts involving men; two others showed children with their genitals exposed. The jurors told the Enquirer they believed the five pictures of sex acts to be offensive and designed to appeal to prurient interests. But they said expert witnesses convinced them the photographs had artistic value. To be considered obscene under Supreme Court guidelines, photographs must depict patently offensive sexual conduct and offend the average member of the community. They also must have no literary, artistic, political, scientific or social value. ``I think there's something to be learned by these pictures,'' said forewoman Stacey Burton, a secretary. ``I learned more about that type of lifestyle than I ever thought I could possibly know,'' said Jennifer Loesing, a hospital supervisor. Six art experts and museum directors testified that the photos were important work by a respected artist. One prosecution witness testified that the pictures had no redeeming value. Ms. Loesing said hat during deliberations she kept thinking of defense lawyer H. Louis Sirkin's ``apple pie'' analogy: that without meeting each requirement of the Supreme Court test, the photographs were not obscene - just as a pie without apples isn't an apple pie. ``That stuck in a lot of our minds,'' she said. Ms. Burton said prosecutors failed to prove their case. ``I think they could have called in a sociologist or psychologist,'' she said. ``Somebody who could have said, `This is not art because. ...''' The jurors said they relied on the opinions of the expert witnesses. Jurors came from conventional backgrounds. None was among the 81,000 people who saw the exhibit. Three of the eight had been to college, six lived in the suburbs and all held jobs. There were four men, four women. Sirkin and fellow defense lawyer Marc Mezibov staked their case on testimony by their expert witnesses. Prosecutor Frank H. Prouty said the seven photographs were his case. Much of the art world was willing to testify for the defense, and Sirkin said he and Mezibov chose their witnesses carefully. They ruled out an expert from Dayton because of its progressive reputation in Cincinnati, and experts from Cleveland and Columbus because of the hostility some Cincinnatians feel toward those cities, Sirkin said. They also didn't want anyone from New York City because of its reputation for licentiousness, Sirkin said. ``Rochester was as close as we wanted to get to New York,'' he said, referring to the testimony of Robert A. Sobieszek, senior curator of photography at the International Museum of Photography in Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Call For Alternative to Red Army Service
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Scores of radical activists, grieving mothers and leather-clad youths rallied side-by-side at the gates of the Defense Ministry Sunday, demanding alternatives to compulsory military service. Several hundred people watched and often applauded as speakers from the fledgling Radical Party, organizers of the rally, criticized the United States and the Soviet Union for the arms buildups they said made the drafts necessary. ``There is no reason for a universal military draft. Who is threatening us? It's our own heaping stockpile that is threatening us,'' said Alexander Kalinina, a Radical Party member and deputy on the Moscow City Council. ``Those who don't want to serve according to their own consciences should be allowed to serve in the civil (sector) instead of the military,'' he told the crowd. The rally on Constitution Day, which marks the adoption of the Soviet Constituion in 1977, was held without official permission. But there were no confrontations with the dozens of policemen posted at each entrance to the white-marble Defense Ministry building. Every Soviet male of 18 or older must serve in the military and can be called up during seasonal draft periods, one of which is occuring this autumn. Soviet officials have admitted that thousands of youths have been ignoring draft orders in the last year. Many refuse to serve outside their home republics because, among other issues, they fear the vicious hazing process that often is ethnically motivated. Beatings and harassment of minorities are so rampant that several republics refused to allow their youths to be drafted this year. One report said 15,000 Soviet soldiers died in the last five years in murders, suicides and training accidents. Kalinina said many of the 3,800 soldiers killed already this year had died of injuries from hazings. ``The mass media have led a campaign against hazings, but it has not been very enthusiastic,'' he said. A half-dozen women, representing an increasingly active mothers' group that seeks more information about their sons who died while in service, staked out an area at the center of the rally. Each of the women held a photo of a soldier and a hand-lettered sign detailing his birth, place of service and date of death. At one point, an elderly woman charged to the front of the group, pulled an olive green officer's hat from a bag and flailed it in the air, wailing and chanting for her son killed in Afghanistan. The speaker hesitated slightly while the woman sobbed and retreated into the crowd. ``We Don't Want To Kill, We Don't Want To Fight,'' said one sign carried by several youths opposed to military service. ``Communist Party Army, Whom Do You Fight For?'' read another. ``We need alternative service like all civilized European countries have,'' said Igor Ptychnikov, leader of a raucous group called the Moscow Committee for Youth Solidarity. ``We want to be able to opt out of military service for religious, conscience and other reasons. We'll serve anywhere but the army.'' He said the group, many of whose members were clad in leather jackets covered with peace slogans and English words, has chapters and 3,000 members in 14 Russian cities. But he said it has none in the surrounding republics because ``We don't want to be occupiers.'' In the crowd also were several anarchists waving black flags and selling literature. Others waved the red-blue-and-white pre-Revolutionary Russian flag, and two people held huge, light blue-and-yellow flags of the nationalist Ukraine.

DOC.HEAD: Hunger Strikers Heed Doctor, End Fast at Fort Benning
DOC.TEXT: Four hunger strikers, who lost a total of 151 pounds protesting the U.S. training of Salvadoran soldiers, ended their 35-day fast Sunday after doctors warned of permanent health damage. ``Our cause continues,'' said the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, a Roman Catholic priest from Lutcher, La., after the strikers ended their fast at a morning news conference. ``The bread we received today is nourishment for us to recommit ourselves.'' Bourgeois was among nine protesters who began the fast Sept. 3, praying, carrying signs and marching outside Fort Benning. The group demanded that the United States cut all military aid to El Salvador and stop training Salvadoran soldiers at the base's Army School of the Americas. The United States is spending some $315 million in aid to El Salvador this year, much of it economic and food aid for an economy racked by a decade-old civil war with leftist guerrillas. A Democratic task force has pressed the Bush administration for restrictions in next year's planned $85 million in military aid to the country in wake of investigations into the slayings of six Jesuit priests in the capital of San Salvador in November 1989. Five of the original protesters dropped the fast over the last two weeks. Remaining were Bourgeois; Jim Barnett, a Dominican priest who served in El Salvador and plans to return now; Charlie Liteky of Washington, D.C., who won a Medal of Honor by pulling 20 wounded men from under enemy fire during the Vietnam War; and David Scott, an ex-Marine and Vietnam veteran from Detroit. Bourgeois said the four decided to end the strike after doctors warned that their weight loss could cause permanent health damage. He said Liteky was warned he could sustain severe kidney damage. Bourgeois said he lost 38 pounds, Liteky 40, Scott 35 and Barnett 38.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuees Stream Out of Embattled Rwanda
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of foreigners crowded onto special flights out of Rwanda's capital on Sunday while government forces and rebels clashed in the northern part of the country. Security in large parts of the Kigali, the capital, and at the airport was being provided by 500 Belgian paratroopers and 300 French Foreign Legionnaires sent in to maintain order and protect foreigners. Zaire also has sent 500 soldiers. Some of the more than 700 refugees flown to France and Belgium recounted the chaos in the country since rebels invaded Sept. 30. Jean-Claude Fayd-Herbe, the World Bank's chief representative in Rwanda, told journalists that he and his family were staying in a hotel in Kigali when rebels attacked early Friday. ``It was chaos. The French paratroopers were shooting, and the people coming from Uganda also were shooting,'' he said upon arrival in Paris. ``In the hotel, there was panic, and the guests barricaded the windows with mattresses. ``The Rwandan soldiers seemed especially nervous, and it seemed they were firing at the French troops.'' A diplomat in Kigali, reached by telephone from Nairobi, reported no violence in the city early Sunday. But he added: ``We've heard reports of continued fighting in the north, including some artillery attacks by the government.'' He said most of those leaving on the special flights were wives and children of aid workers. No governments have ordered evacuations of their citizens. A special Air France flight carrying 252 foreign evacuees from Rwanda arrived in Paris. Aboard were about 100 French citizens and a large contingent of Germans, as well as other nationalities. In Brussels, 463 refugees arrived aboard three Belgian planes. More than 200 of the refugees were Belgian. Others were Dutch, American, German and Danish. Up to 1,000 foreigners have left Kigali on special flights since late Friday, the diplomatic source in Rwanda said on condition of anonymity. Friday's fighting in Kigali lasted only a few hours, but there were fears the conflict could degenerate into the ethnic violence that has plagued Rwanda in the past. The rebels belong mostly to Rwanda's minority Tutsi ethnic group. They were chased from power three decades ago by the majority Hutu tribe in clan fighting that killed tens of thousands of people. During those clashes, more than 100,000 Tutsis fled to neighboring Uganda, Zaire and Tanzania, where they have been living as refugees ever since. The diplomat said government soldiers were conducting house-to-house searches in some parts of Kigali, but it was not clear whether they were looking for arms or Tutsis. Tutsis are generally distinguishable from the shorter, stockier Hutus by their tall, lanky physiques. Many of the rebels are said to be deserters from the Ugandan army. Their numbers never have been reliably estimated. Figures cited by various diplomatic sources have ranged from a few hundred to several thousand. They are led by Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a Rwandan Tutsi who rose to become the deputy commander of Uganda's army. He was relieved of the post late last year. The rebels accuse President Juvenal Habyarimana of abuse of power and corruption and say they want to install a democratic government. They deny that theirs is an ethnic war. The rebels also say they want to end the refugee problem. Rwanda has been reluctant to readmit its refugees because of a lack of space. Pope John Paul II on Sunday called for peace in Rwanda, which he visited on an African tour last month. ``We pray for an end to the clashes of these recent days, and that that beloved nation ... can find peace in justice as soon as possible,'' the pontiff said. The Central African nation, about the size of Maryland, is the continent's most densely populated. An average of 566 people occupy every rocky and eroded square mile. That compares to an average of 63 people per square mile in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: New Volcanoes Found Off Oregon Coast
DOC.TEXT: A 10-mile string of about 10 new volcanoes has been discovered on the ocean floor about 300 miles off the Oregon Coast, scientists said. The volcanoes, some more than 100 feet high and a half-mile wide, were spotted by scientists studying maps and photographs of the sea floor along the Juan de Fuca Ridge, which runs north and south off the Washington and Oregon coasts. They were formed within the past decade, said Robert Embley, a marine geologist with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory in Newport. Photographs taken last year and topographic surveys in August showed new cones that did not appear in 1981 surveys. In August, scientists using the submersible Alvin found fresh lava flows extending into and over a large fracture in the sea floor. The volcanoes ``are not continuous,'' but they are difficult to count because some have joined together, Embley said in a story published Sunday in The Oregonian. They ``are not huge like Mount St. Helens, but they can be described more as volcanic mounds.'' Embley made the discovery with William Chadwick, a research associate with Oregon State University, and Christopher Fox, a remote-sensing specialist with NOAA. The researchers work at the Hatfield Marine Science Center. ``This is a big step,'' Embley said. ``It's the first time we can actually see a sea-floor spreading event. I'm sure we're going to learn a lot about how eruptions occur and what happens during these events.'' Lava comes up from magma chambers beneath such midocean ridges, where the sea floor forms and spreads. Embley said the volcanoes are about 1{ miles deep, on the crest of the Juan de Fuca Ridge, where the Juan de Fuca and the Pacific tectonic plates form. The Juan de Fuca Plate creeps eastward toward the continent from the ridge, while the Pacific Plate moves westward. The plates are huge slabs of the Earth's crus. The volcanoes may be related to gigantic bursts of hot, mineral-rich water called ``megaplumes,'' Embley said. The megaplumes were discovered by NOAA scientists in 1986 and 1987. One measured about 12 miles in diameter and 2,000 feet thick.

DOC.HEAD: Former Utah Governor Scott Matheson Dies at 61
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, `Dwan said ...' to add details of survivors.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SK1
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Scott Matheson died of bone marrow cancer Sunday at the University of Utah Health Sciences Center, a hospital spokesman said. He was 61. The popular two-term Democrat died at 5 a.m., just over a month after first receiving treatment for the cancer, multiple myeloma, said hospital spokesman John Dwan. He had been in and out of the hospital several times since Sept. 4. Matheson served as the state's 12th governor from 1977 to 1985, choosing not to seek re-election despite consistent favorable ratings in the polls. As governor, Matheson successfully opposed placement of the MX missile system in the state's western desert, battled to continue funding of the massive Central Utah water control project and was given high marks for decisive action when parts of the state were devastated by flooding in 1983. ``The news of Scott Matheson's death comes as a shock to me,'' said Republican Gov. Norm Bangerter, who was speaker of the House while Matheson was governor. ``I am deeply saddened by his passing,'' Bangerter said. ``I had the privilege of working closely with Scott during his eight years as governor when I was in House leadership. I always found he was a man true to his word. In my view he had complete integrity.'' ``While we belonged to different political parties, Scott Matheson never let politics get in the way of doing what was right for the people of Utah.'' After eight years in office, Matheson said in late 1988, ``the hours began to wear me down.'' ``I never slept in as governor, and for five of my eight years in office, I never took a vacation,'' he said. ``I immersed myself completely in the job, but I loved it.'' The former counsel for Union Pacific Railroad was a political unknown when he was backed for the job by three-term Democratic governor Calvin L. Rampton, who had decided to return to the practice of law. With Rampton's support, Matheson defeated former Republican attorney general Vernon Romney in 1976 and won re-election in 1980 over former GOP state chairman Robert Wright. After leaving office, he was appointed chairman of the Democratic National Policy Council in 1985, and at his death was a partner in the Salt Lake law firm of Parsons, Behle & Latimer. Earlier this year, Matheson withdrew his name from consideration as President Bush's nuclear waste negotiator, citing personal reasons. As governor, he was an outspoken opponent of locating a high-level nuclear waste repository in his native southern Utah. In 1983 he suffered a mild heart attack, spent two weeks in a hospital and returned to work. In May 1987, Matheson announced he would not challenge Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch in the 1988 election, saying ``personal considerations regarding my family and expanding responsibilities as a private attorney figure largely in this decision.'' When Matheson ruled out a bid for a third term, the governor's chair was won by Bangerter, ending 20 years of Democratic control of the office. Bangerter was re-elected in 1988 after Matheson turned thumbs down on a possible return to the Capitol. Dwan said aatheson's family would have no comment for at least 24 hours. He is survived by his wife, Norma; three sons; and a daughter. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: New York City Begins Television Adoption Ads
DOC.TEXT: The city begins airing television commercials Monday in an effort to find homes for some of the 7,000 children in foster care. The Human Resources Administration will rotate 24 spots on WNBC-TV through mid-January. The 10-second ads will feature 29 children between 8 and 16, including some siblings. They'll include a one-sentence description of the child and his or her interests, plus a flashing telephone number. Many of the youngsters have learning disabilities or are teen-agers from minority groups, considered difficult to place. ``I wanted to get adopted so that I could stay with my sister,'' said a 15-year-old boy, identified only as Robert, who appears in one of the ads. His sister, who lives in a different group home, did not want to be in the commercial. ``Most people like to adopt little children,'' Robert said in an interview. ``Grownups are afraid older kids might get in trouble.'' Suffolk County aired similar spots on a cable TV channel several years ago. ``It works,'' said Robert Oliveri, a spokesman for that county's Social Services Department. ``But it doesn't make a lasting impression. You get a momentary flurry of calls, very specific to a child. There is no carryover effect to other children.''

DOC.HEAD: Tehran Reported Tense On Eve Of Vote For Key Assembly
DOC.TEXT: Security forces were on alert in Tehran Sunday, the eve of elections for the body that pick's Iran's spiritual leader, as radicals excluded from running were expected to try to block voting, sources said. One Asian diplomat described the Iranian capital as ``disturbed and tense'' ahead of Monday's popular poll for the 83-member Assembly of Experts. He declined to elaborate. The diplomat, speaking from Tehran, said security forces were watching for any demonstrations against the controversial balloting, which radicals charge has been rigged to exclude them. The radicals want the vote postponed. The assembly is the constitutional body that chooses and monitors Iran's spiritual leader. The current spiritual leader is Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. The hard-line opponents of President Hashemi Rafsanjani - leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists - accuse Khamenei of colluding with Rafsanjani to fix the elections. The conflict over the balloting has heightened tension between the rival factions and brought the long-running power struggle in Tehran's hierarchy more prominently into the public eye. Fistfights erupted in the radical-dominated parliament, or Majlis, during a debate on the vote last week, sources in Tehran said on condition of anonymity. Diplomats, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said that radicals attempted to meet last Wednesday and Saturday at Tehran University, apparently to organize protests, but both meetings were broken up by security forces. The anti-Western radicals, led by former interior minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, have been on the defensive since the death of their revolutionary patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, in June 1989. They fear a purge by Rafsanjani, who is seeking to rebuild bridges with the West after more than a decade of hostility and attract investment to revive the sluggish economy, devastated from the 1980-1988 Persian Gulf war with Iraq. Radicals suffered a further blow last month when Tehran resumed relations with Britain after a 19-month break. Radical leaders believe such ties will dilute Khomeini's zealous 1979 revolution, which overthrew the pro-Western Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and replaced him with the Islamic Republic. The official Islamic Republic News Agency reported that Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Golpayegani, one of a handful of supreme religious authorities in the country, sought to ease tension between the factions Sunday. He reminded the feuding groups that ``only the enemies of Islam would benefit from disputes and schisms, especially among officials,'' IRNA said. The radicals, angered by Khamenei's support for Rafsanjani, have focused on discrediting him. Khamenei, 51, was overwelmingly elected by the Assembly of Experts to replace the Ayatollah Khomeini. He can be replaced only if he dies or is declared unfit for the position by the Assembly. The radicals have charged that he does not have the religious qualifications to be Khomeini's successor. Sources in Tehran said the hard-liners had wanted to win enough seats in Monday's election to depose Khamenei and replace him with a radical-controlled leadership council. To preempt that, Khamenei ordered his allies on the Council of Guardians, a constitutional watchdog body, to rule that all candidates must pass an examination on Islamic jurisprudence before they could run. Of 169 would-be candidates who sat for the exam, 60 flunked, and most were radicals, including Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi, sources said. Some radicals refused to submit to the examination. Others who did pass withdrew their names in protest. Iran's 25 million voters have been exhorted for days by the state-controlled radio and television - run by Rafsanjani's brother - to vote, despite the radical protests. Interior Minister Abdollah Nouri said 100 candidates were running in the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Sumitomo Bank Chairman Resigning Over Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Sumitomo Bank, among the world's three largest banks, resigned Sunday over a scandal involving illegal loans used to manipulate the stock of an aerial survey company. Ichiro Isoda, 77, who led Sumitomo's growth into Japan's most profitable bank, announced his resignation following the arrest Friday of Akinori Yamashita, a former branch manager. Yamashita was arrested on suspicion of having arranged about $170 million in illegal loans to two groups allegedly involved in stock manipulation. ``It is only natural to take responsibility as the top manager of the bank, in light of the bank's public role,'' Isoda told a news conference. He said Sumitomo's president, Sotoo Tatsumi, also had expressed his intention to resign, but Isoda persuaded him not to do so. Officials said the bank had not been aware of Yamashita's actions. In Japan, leaders of organizations often resign to take responsibility for the misdeeds of subordinates, even if they were not personally involved. News reports said Yamashita arranged for bank depositors to provide a loan of $85 million at higher-than-normal interest rates to Koshin, a speculators' group, and a separate loan of $86 million to another group, Tosho Shoji. The loan to Koshin was used to buy up stocks of Kokusai Kogyo, a Tokyo-based aerial survey company, the news report said. The nationally circulated newspaper Asahi Shimbun quoted investigators as saying Yamashita received more than $748,000 and inside stock information for arranging the loans. Under Japan's Financing Law, bank employees are prohibited from engaging in loan transactions outside their company's normal business operations. Those convicted face a maximum three-year prison term and a $22,000 fine. Mitsuhiro Kotani, head of Koshin, has been indicted on charges of manipulating stocks in violation of the Securities and Exchange Law, Kyodo News Service said. The Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, on Sunday called for a full investigation into the loans and said extensive lending for real estate and stock transactions had contributed to spiraling land and stock prices. ``As a result, the prices of both corporate stocks and land were inflated far beyond their actual values, like a bubble,'' it said in an editorial. ``Most observers believe this year's plunge of stock prices ... was the result of the bursting of this bubble.'' The Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei Stock Average reached a record high of 38,915.87 last Dec. 29, but has plunged about 42 percent since then. Some of the recent fall reflects business pessimism as a result of the gulf crisis. Japan has only 4 percent of the United States' land area but its real estate is estimated at nearly four times the total value of U.S. real estate - about $15 trillion. Sumitomo Bank had pre-tax profits of $2.7 billion in fiscal 1989, the largest sum of Japan's 13 major commercial banks, Kyodo News Service said. The bank reported total assets of $470 billion in March 1990, putting it slightly behind the world's largest bank, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, which reported $497 billion in assets. Asset figures were not available for Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, created earlier this year in a merger of two major Japanese banks and close to Sumitomo in size.

DOC.HEAD: Widow of Pepperdine University Founder Dead at Age 87
DOC.TEXT: Helen Davis Pepperdine, whose late husband founded Pepperdine University, has died of heart failure at age 87, officials said. Mrs. Pepperdine died Friday at Los Angeles Midway Hospital, where she was taken earlier in the day after complaining of chest pains, said university spokesman Jeff Bliss. ``She was a grand lady loved by all who knew her,'' Pepperdine President David Davenport said. ``She truly cherished the opportunity to be involved with students and all of us at the university.'' A native of Muncie, Ind., she moved with her family to Los Angeles in 1919 and worked as a photographer. She married George Pepperdine in 1934. Soon after, the couple founded the Helen Louise Girls Home, which catered to young women from broken homes. In 1937, Pepperdine opened the George Pepperdine College in Los Angeles, which expanded into the private, liberal arts university that now sits atop a hill in Malibu overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Although her husband died in 1962, Mrs. Pepperdine remained active at the university and served as a Board of Regents member until her death. A memorial service will be held next week at the campus, some 30 miles west of downtown Los Angeles. She is survived by the couple's three children and several grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Fund-Raiser's Memo to Cranston Notes Keating's Problems
DOC.TEXT: A ``confidential'' memo to Sen. Alan Cranston from a key fund-raiser indicates that savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. was among several campaign supporters who expected resolution of requests for help from the senator, The Washington Post reported Sunday. The fund-raiser, Joy Jacobson, also suggested in a second memo that Cranston seek a $250,000 contribution from Keating for Cranston's voter registration drive, the Post said. The second memo followed a series of meetings between the California Democrat and Keating and separate meetings with federal thrift regulators to discuss their inquiries into Keating's Irving, Calif.-based Lincoln Savings and Loan. Regulators eventually shut down Lincoln, and the government estimates the thrift's failure will cost taxpayers $2 billion. Cranston and four other senators - Dennis DeConcini, R-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz. - are under investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with federal regulators on behalf of Keating and his California thrift. Keating has been indicted on fraud charges in California in connection with the thrift's failure. A Cranston spokesman, Murray Flander, refused to comment on the report Sunday other than to say ``That information properly belongs to the ethics committee and was improperly leaked by someone.'' ``We won't comment on improperly leaked information,'' Flander said. Cranston has said his motivations were to see that a constituent was treated fairly and not the money. Keating also raised $40,000 for Cranston's 1986 campaign and contributed $85,000 to the California Democratic Party. In the first memo, dated Jan. 2, 1987, Jacobson told Cranston that Keating was one of five campaign supporters who ``rightfully expect some kind of resolution'' for pending requests for help from the senator. The memo said the contributors had been very helpful to Cranston and other Democrats in their successful effort to win back majority control of the Senate in 1986. In the second memo in September 1987, Jacobson told Cranston, ``You should ask Keating for $250,000,'' the Post said. Jacobson, in the same memo, also suggested asking an American Express executive for $100,000 for voter registration and said she was trying to make appointments with since-convicted junk bond king Michael Milken and billionaire developer Donald Trump, the newspaper said. Cranston ultimately raised $7 million for various nonpartisan, tax-exempt voter registration groups. The September memo referred to Lincoln's ``problems with the Bank Board and Ed Gray.'' The Post said the memo was attached to a news story about M. Danny Wall's replacing Gray as head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and said the change was ``obviously ... good news to Keating.'' Jacobson also had mentioned the problems in the earlier note, according to the Post.

DOC.HEAD: Cranky Tourists Clog Capitol During Government Shutdown ^Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs, bgng: ``Unfortunately, we, to UPDATE with chorus of boos from gallery
DOC.TEXT: Shut out of other federal tourist attractions, frustrated visitors from around the world flocked to the Capitol on Sunday to see the legislature in action and give lawmakers a piece of their mind. ``They should have settled the budget instead of going on vacation,'' said 20-year-old Kara DiMugno of Southington, Conn., referring to the long recess members of Congress took in August. Like thousands of other tourists, DiMugno, a senior at the University of Rhode Island, came to the Capitol because it was the best show in Washington, one of the few sites that has not been closed because of the budget stalemate between President Bush and Congress. ``Unfortunately we are the only game in town so our tour guides are really busy,'' said Tom Keating, executive assistant to the House sergeant at arms. Although open, the action in the Capitol was limited at best. When the House came into session at 4 p.m. - only to recess again moments later - loud booing erupted from the galleries packed with tourists. The Capitol is regularly open on Sundays and is always open when members are working. Weekend sessions like the ones scheduled by the House and Senate on Sunday are rare. On this balmy, sunny October day, thousands of tourists were locked out of some of the nation's most historic sights for the second day: the 13 Smithsonian Institution museums, including the air and space museum, one of the most popular in the world; the White House; the Library of Congress; and the Washington Monument. The shutdown affects non-essential government personnel nationwide. But federal operations deemed essential, such as those involving aviation, health, law enforcement and security, are not affected by the crisis. Monday is a federal holiday - Columbus Day - so federal employees are to report to work as usual Tuesday when those considered non-essential can expect to be sent home within three hours. Meantime, Democratic leaders predicted there would be a budget agreement before Tuesday's drop-dead day. ``We're going to have a budget package today or tomorrow - we hope today,'' said House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash. The House had adjourned until mid-afternoon while the Senate did not plan to come into session until early evening. For some tourists, it was too late. ``We're very disappointed,'' said Brenda Marlatt, a nurse from Ocean, N.J., spending the long weekend here. Marlatt, a single mother who has scrimped to bring her daughters ages 10 and 8 to the nation's capital to see the sights, pronounced the budget situation ``a total mess. ... Why can't they just pass it?'' Mike Sanders, owner of an auto repair shop in Concord, Calif., planned a more direct approach: he wanted to share his views with his congressman, Rep. George Miller, D-Calif. Sanders said he was angry that Democrats and Republicans ganged up to kill Bush's deficit plan late Thursday. Miller, a liberal, was one of those voting against it. ``We really feel reducing the deficit is important,'' said Sanders' wife, LeeAnn. If the United States falls deeper into debt, ``these kids will never be able to pay for it,'' Sanders added, pointing as his sons, ages 6 and 4. Many members of Congress who rejected the budget deal because they felt it contained new taxes that might be unpalatable to voters in an election year now found themselves confronting criticism for not passing it. But Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., said most of the complaints he had heard came from federal workers and cranky tourists, not his constituents. Even so, Murtha said, ``We made a mistake'' in Congress by rejecting the budget agreement and refusing to follow the lead of the Democratic leaders and Bush. Murtha voted for the package. This is not the first time the government has run out of spending authority. Squabbles between the administration and Congress forced the temporary closing of government three times in the last decade.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Clash Reported in Soviet Crimea
DOC.TEXT: Extra police were sent to the region around the Black Sea resort of Yalta after a clash between residents and Crimean Tatars living in makeshift tent camps, Pravda reported Sunday. Stalin forcibly expelled the Tatars from the Crimea, but thousands have been filtering back in recent years from Siberia and Central Asia, the lands to which they were banished during World War II. Traffic police have blocked the roads to Yalta since last week, when two tent camps housing resettled Crimean Tatars were attacked and destroyed. The police are checking motorists' identification to keep any more Crimean Tatars from entering the region, Pravda said. There are 21 tent camps in the area housing more than 2,500 Tatars, according to the independent Interfax news agency. A spokesman for the ethnic movement said residents of a tent camp in Koreiz, near Yalta, built a barricade and prepared to defend the settlement, Interfax reported. During the war, Stalin sent several ethnic groups into internal exile on the grounds that they could not be trusted to occupy strategic areas. The Tatars and other groups have been agitating to be allowed to return to their traditional homes. In 1989, the Supreme Soviet declared that all peoples exiled under Stalin should be considered politically rehabilitated. But other residents now occupy the lands and houses that belonged to the exiles, and conflicts have arisen when some groups try to reestablish themselves. Ethnographers estimate there are 500,000 Crimean Tatars in the Soviet Union, and 1 million more in Turkey. Angry protests in Moscow by Tatar exiles in 1987 were among the first tests of President Mikhail Gorbachev's promises of greater democracy.

DOC.HEAD: EC Nations Debate Role In Foreign, Defense Policy
DOC.TEXT: The 12 European Community nations, in informal weekend talks, opened an ambitious debate on how to grant the community a formal role in foreign and defense issues. The talks among the EC foreign ministers centered on a 17-page discussion paper, drafted by Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis, on how to transfer national authority in defense and security matters to the EC. The talks began Saturday and ended Sunday. De Michelis said that while the EC nations disagree on key points, ``all are committed to finding a convergent approach'' when talks on turning the community into a political union formally begin in Rome in December. His discussion paper suggests that the community consider bringing the activities of the Western European Union - a long-dormant defense organization of nine European NATO members - under the EC's wings. A joint EC security policy could extend to military cooperation and disarmament and ``coordinated participation in military initiatives, in particular in the context of U.N.-mandated action,'' the report says. The paper, based on discussions with senior EC political officials, offers no recommendations on how much sovereignty in defense EC nations should retain. At Sunday's session, the foreign ministers also discussed scenarios under which the community could create a formal foreign policy role that would be acceptable to all 12 nations, officials said on condition of anonymity. Only Belgium and Italy strongly endorsed the notion of letting the Western European Union merge with the EC. Britain, France and the Netherlands were more cautious. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said he ``would like to see the European pillar of NATO strengthened.'' He said Sunday's talks showed ``not much enthusiasm for the fusion of the'' Western European Union into the EC. Officials said Britain fears that endowing the EC with a role in defense matters would weaken the link between Western Europe and its U.S. and Canadian allies. The community said Sunday it wants to sign declarations with the United States and Canada within the next six weeks, stressing political and economic links across the Atlantic. The EC foreign ministers will continue to discuss political union in the weeks ahead. They are also considering giving a greater say in EC affairs to the European Parliament, the largely advisory 518-member assembly that meets once a month in Strasbourg, France. In December, negotiations begin on amending the community's 1957 founding treaty to elevate the EC from a trade bloc to an organization with a collective foreign policy. The talks on political union will be held concurrently with negotiations on creating an EC central bank and a common EC currency. The 12 members of the European Community are Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Spain and Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Gainesville Slayings Suspect Faces Assault Count
DOC.TEXT: A much-publicized suspect in the Gainesville student slayings is going to trial on a charge of beating his 79-year-old grandmother, and his lawyers say it won't be easy to pick an impartial jury. Edward Lewis Humphrey has been under intense scrutiny since his Aug. 29 arrest by Brevard County authorities. Soon after that, investigators named him as a suspect in the slayings of five college students. Humphrey has been jailed on $1 million bond and if convicted, could be sentenced to as much as 5{ years in prison. However, his grandmother, Elna Hlavaty, says she will testify she was injured in a fall and wasn't hit by Humphrey. The trial begins Monday with jury selection, which officials in the Brevard County public defender's office warn could be lengthy. They are worried that news media coverage of the Gainesville investigation may have damaged Humphrey's chance for a fair hearing on the charge of aggravated assault on the elderly. ``I think it will take quite a while,'' said Gene Stevanus, executive director of the public defender's office. News accounts have told of police searching Humphrey's property, towing away his car and taking various samples of his body tissue, along with his history of violent threats, nighttime ``reconnaissance missions,'' his fondness for knives, and his mental illness tied to a car accident. Recently, authorities investigating the Gainesville slayings have appeared to back away from Humphrey as a suspect. They have made little public comment, but they have warned Gainesville residents to be careful because the killer could still be loose. Mrs. Hlavaty, who initially said her grandson hit her, now says she fell and injured herself the night her grandson came home from school. Mrs. Hlavaty said she is looking forward to the trial as the only way for family members to put the nightmare behind them.

DOC.HEAD: Juan Jose Arevalo, Former Guatemalan President, Dead at 86
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT dates of Mendez Montenegro's term, ADD that Arevalo served as ambassador to Chile, wrote book critical of U.S., is survived by widow; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Juan Jose Arevalo Bermejo, a former president whose civilian government was considered a shining moment for the poor in a nation dominated by military governments, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 86. Arevalo died at the Spanish Hospital in the Guatemalan capital late Saturday, said his sister-in-law, America Barahona de Arevalo. She did not give the cause of death. Arevalo, a former university professor in the humanities, returned to Guatemala from Argentina following a 1944 popular uprising that ended the 14-year-old military dictatorship of Jorge Ubico. Becoming president the following year, he set about carrying out social reforms akin to those of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the United States. During his six years in office, Arevalo established a social security system, began agrarian reforms and worked to integrate the Indians, who made up about half the population, into the nation. In 1951, he turned the government over to his elected successor, Col. Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, who expanded the reforms under a center-left administration until he was overthrown in a U.S.-backed revolt in 1954. Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, who led the CIA-funded rebels in an invasion from Honduras, took power until his assassination in 1957. A series of right-wing military governments followed, and a leftist insurgency began in 1960 and still continues today. ``Within Guatemalan history, Arevalo will stand out as a kind of founding father of modern Guatemala,'' said Stephen Schlesinger, co-author of the Guatemalan history ``Bitter Fruit: The Untold Story of the American Coup in Guatemala.'' ``What he will be remembered for is this extraordinary time - the only time, really, since its creation in 1821 - that it had a government that was compassionate toward the poor and the Indians,'' Schlesinger said in a telephone interview in New York. Arevalo was one of only two civilian Guatemalan chief executives in the past 60 years to complete his term. The other was Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro, who served from 1966 to 1970. Arevalo was ambassador to Chile under Mendez Montenegro. Elections are set for November to replace civilian President Vinicio Cerezo, elected in 1985. Arevalo wrote several books, among them ``The Shark and the Sardine,'' a criticism of U.S. policy in Latin America. He was to be buried in Taxisco, 65 miles southeast of Guatemala, where he was born Sept. 10, 1904. The government was expected to declare a day of mourning. Arevalo is survived by his widow, Margarita de Leon; their five children; a sister, Marina Arevalo de Meneses, and a brother, Mariano Arevalo Bermejo. Schlesinger said Arevalo's ``legacy will be that he was a shining moment in Guatemala's political history, a moment that was extinguished by the 1954 American coup. ``He's still a symbol of a moment of hope in Guatemala's history, a symbol that many Guatemalans hope will be reflected in change in the coming decade.''

DOC.HEAD: Reports Say De Klerk, Mandela to Meet Monday
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela have set a meeting for Monday to discuss recent black factional fighting, newspapers reported. The ANC called last week for a meeting with de Klerk on the violence in black townships around Johannesburg, which has killed about 800 people since erupting Aug. 12. The fighting has pitted Zulu followers of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC, the nation's largest anti-apartheid group. It has strained relations between the white-led government and the ANC. Mandela and other black leaders have accused security forces of instigating the street fighting in a bid to destabilize the country and derail peace talks with the government. ``These groups want to destroy the ANC so that we would take up arms and fight among ourselves,'' Mandela told a rally Sunday in Pietermaritzburg, in eastern Natal Province. De Klerk and government officials have denied the charge. They have challenged the ANC to provide proof of security force involvement and pledged to investigate any allegations. News reports Sunday said Mandela would present de Klerk with affidavits Monday backing his claims of security force involvement in the violence. Scattered incidents of violence were reported Sunday in Johannesburg area townships. Police reported three Xhosa men were killed in Daveyton, east of Johannesburg, in a dispute with Zulus. Police Lt. Henriette Bester said two Zulu men were arrested and two handguns confiscated. She said the clash Saturday appeared to be isolated. Police also reported that two men were burned to death in separate incidents in Sebokeng, to the south, and Tembisa, which is north of the city. The fighting has eased in recent weeks after periods in which dozens of blacks died daily. The government last month imposed measures designed to stop the fighting in some of the most seriously affected townships. The measures included weapons searches, roadblocks and a 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew. Authorities lifted the curfew in the sprawling township of Soweto last week. De Klerk also announced an amnesty for people and organizations turning in illegal weapons. Police said Sunday more than 3,200 weapons had been turned in, and that the amnesty would extend until the end of the month. Most of the weapons turned over have been handguns and rifles. Police said only five traditional ``terrorist'' weapons, including an AK-47 assault rifle and a machine gun, have been recovered in the program. De Klerk has pledged to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. He has led the government in talks with the ANC aimed at setting up negotiations on sharing power with the black majority. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites control the government and economy. The 30 million blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Federal `Shutdown' Little Noticed Except At Some National Parks
With AM-Budget-Not Shutdown Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Vacationing Americans have been hardest hit so far by the budget stalemate, encountering ``closed'' signs at Montana's Custer Battlefield National Monument and locked gates at the White House. The federal government technically shut down at 12:01 a.m. Saturday, except for essential services, but that was the first day of a three-day Columbus Day holiday weekend. As a result, most federal employee did not anticipate returning to work until Tuesday. Workers were told to report to their jobs Tuesday, at which time non-essential personnel will be sent home within the first three hours if there is no budget agreement. Congressional Democrats say they hope to have a budget agreement with the Bush administration by then, thereby allowing government to resume spending money and averting a widespread halt in government services. The shutdown affects non-essential government personnel nationwide. But federal operations deemed essential, such as those involving aviation, health, law enforcement and security, are not affected by the crisis. Normal weekend operations were in effect, for example, at the Defense Department and at the Federal Aviation Administration. Over the weekend, the most visible impact of the budget impasse fell on the National Park Service, which runs mountain and seaside resorts from coast-to-coast. In Texas, visitors were turned away from seashores and mountain lodges. At Big Bend National Park in West Texas, spokesman Roy Given had to notify guests on Saturday they were no longer welcome at the remote wilderness park. The park hotel, restaurant and stables will remain open, but Big Bend no longer is offering its guided tours, campground facilities or its back country and river permits. A busload of tourists from Indiana drove six hours to reach the Great Smoky Mountain National Park, only to be turned away by rangers Saturday at Clingman's Dome, the highest point in the park. At Yosemite National Park in California, some 7,000 campers were told they would have to clear out by 1 p.m. Sunday because of the budget crisis. ``I think it's horrible,'' said Becky Vaccarezza of Stockton, who months ago had made reservations for a week-long vacation with five other adults and six children. Yosemite superintendent Michael Finley said he was told by Interior Department officials in Washington not to close the park, but to curtail all operations except emergency services. In Michigan, layoffs were reported at the Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore at Munising and at the Sleeping Bear Dunes on Lake Michigan near Empire. In the nation's capital, thousands of tourists were locked out of some of the nation's most historic sights for the second day: the 13 Smithsonian Institution museums, including the air and space museum, one of the most popular in the world; the White House; the Library of Congress; and the Washington Monument. But cranky visitors flooded the Capitol where lawmakers met to try to iron out a deal. Many complained about the cutback in services. The House gallery rocked with boos when the House recessed five minutes after convening at 4 p.m. Although the lawmakers arranged to reconvene when there was something on the budget to consider, the frustrated tourists were not happy with what they saw. In Washington state, Olympic National Park shut down and Mount Rainier National Park closed all but one small campground. In Arkansas, five national parks were closed. Some tourists found an unexpected boon as a result of the crisis. In Florida, ticket takers at Everglades National Park were sent home, allowing motorists to drive in free. At the opposite end of the state, Jerry Eubanks, supervisor of the Gulf Islands National Seashore headquartered in Gulf Breeze, said the park will remain open. ``We have looked at alternatives,'' he said. ``We've just refreshed in our own minds what are essential health and safety measures, but we have no plans as of now for shutting down.'' There was also confusion about what was open and what was not. In Iowa, visitors could tour the Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum buildings operated by the National ARchives and REcords Administration. But other buildings on the grounds, run by the park service, were locked up. Federal employees, meantime, tried to enjoy their holiday. ``I probably should be worried, but I'm not,'' said Doug Druliner, a hydrologist with the U.S. Geological Survey in Nebraska. ``We've gone through this thing in the past, but there was not as much hype about it. We've had furloughs in the past and been paid later.''

DOC.HEAD: Mobil's CEO Ordered To Testify in Civil Suit Against Firm
DOC.TEXT: The head of Mobil Oil Corp. has been ordered to testify this week in a lawsuit by a former company environmental officer who says he was fired for refusing to help cover up problems at one of its plants. Mobil's chief executive officer, Allen E. Murray, was ordered by a federal judge last week to testify in U.S. District Court in a civil suit filed against the nation's second largest oil company. The trial resumes Wednesday. Plaintiff Valcar Bowman was fired in 1986 as the No. 2 environmental officer for Mobil Chemical Co. He wants his old job back, along with back pay and legal costs. Mobil denies Bowman's claims that his ethical purity got him fired. The company says Bowman was fired as part of a cost-cutting campaign and for insubordination and disobedience. In a hearing last year, U.S. District Judge Harold Ackerman noted that Bowman lost his job in 1986, Mobil Chemical's best year ever with a record $140 million in profits, up 164 percent from 1985. Bowman doesn't deny being obstreperous, at one point saying that effective environmental managers ``are not going to win a popularity contest.'' The dispute between Bowman and the company stems from an investigation by Los Angeles authorities into alleged air pollution violations at Mobil's oil refinery in Torrance, Calif. On July 18, 1985, the Los Angeles County district attorney, search warrant in hand, swept unannounced into the Torrance facilityaand emerged with boxes of documents detailing alleged violations. The raid shocked Mobil, which feared a similar search of the Mobil Chemical Co. plant in Bakersfield, Calif. According to company documents, Mobil ordered Bowman's staff to deliver all records not required by law to be kept at the plant to the company's outside counsel, Lawrence Straw. The theory was that attorney-client privilege would keep the documents confidential and out of the hands of snooping investigators, according to Charles Lindberg, Mobil's chief in-house lawyer. ``It would be more difficult for any agency to obtain any of the information delivered to Mr. Straw than it would for them to obtain that information from Mobil directly under subpoena,'' Lindberg wrote. Bowman says he opposed transferring the documents as unethical and immoral and that Mobil knew an inspection of the plant was imminent. Ackerman, in a December hearing, described Mobil's effort to get the documents out of the plant and into Straw's hands as ``frantic.'' It is expected that Murray will be questioned about the transferred documents and his response to a memo Bowman sent to the CEO about environmental negligence and irresponsibility at the firm. The trial has been going on for five weeks, mostly consumed with highly technical testimony by Bowman.

DOC.HEAD: Deadly Hereditary Disease Cuts Swath in Rural Louisiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maigon cq.
DOC.TEXT: An untreatable, fatal genetic disease thought confined to the descendants of Eastern European Jews has turned up in this heavily Catholic community. Nobody knows how Tay-Sachs disease got here, but it apparently is turning up at an even higher rate than among Jews. Babies with Tay-Sachs develop normally until they are about 6 or 7 months old.
