After that, they degenerate slowly but steadily, taking years to die. ``It's so awful to sit and watch your child deteriorate,'' said Renee Abshire, whose daughter, Maigon, died of Tay-Sachs less than two months after her third birthday. ``She lived with constant pneumonia, constant coughing,'' Mrs. Abshire said. ``The last six months of her life, I'd sit and cry.'' Mrs. Abshire, 26, was checked twice during her pregnancy for deformities or hereditary problems in the developing fetus. Her obstetrician never checked for Tay-Sachs. It didn't seem necessary. Testing for Tay-Sachs is routine in many Jewish communities, but Renee and David Abshire are fundamentalist Christians and unaware of any Jewish ancestors. Talking with doctors around southwest Louisiana, Mrs. Abshire, now president of the local Tay-Sachs & Allied Diseases Association chapter, found three other children with Tay-Sachs. None was Jewish. And in three of the four cases, including hers, at least one parent had attended Iota High School. The connection made this Cajun town of 1,200 people something of a genetic ground zero. Three cases weren't an epidemic, but were enough to make people wonder how a rogue gene, a destroyer of children, had slipped into their bloodlines. ``In this small a community, you'd never see this many cases, so you can say it's kind of an explosion,'' said Dr. Michael Quinn, a Crowley pediatrician who treats children from Iota. ``It has to be that someone moved there years and years ago, and two families had the gene, and through intermarriage right in the Iota area, that's where the disease is concentrated.'' Dr. Emmanuel Shapira, a Tulane Medical Center geneticist, checked the blood from 230 townspeople in July. More people wanted to be tested, but Shapira ran out of test kits. The results, he said, were astonishing. ``It's very, very high - at a level to justify screening every couple that wants to have children,'' he said. ``As many as 5 percent are going to be born with it.'' He said 17 of the people he screened carried the gene that can cause Tay-Sachs. That's 7.4 percent, or nearly double the carrier rate among Jews and about 20 times the rate among the entire population. A child with Tay-Sachs lacks a crucial enzyme the body needs to break down fatty deposits in brain and nerve cells. Without the enzyme, deposits accumulate disastrously. The nervous system stops working. Muscle tone vanishes. Respiratory problems develop. It is always fatal, usually before the age of 5. The disease is on a gene carried by about 4 percent of all Jews and about a tenth that rate in the entire population. There is no reliable estimate of the number of cases, said Marjorie Epstein, a spokeswoman for the National Tay-Sachs & Allied Diseases Association. Carrier couples who try to have children face another tough decision: what to do if a prenatal test shows the fetus has Tay-Sachs. Abortion is frowned upon in this conservative, overwhelmingly Catholic section of Louisiana. The Abshires have decided not to try to conceive again. ``The hardest decision for me if I got pregnant again would be to terminate my pregnancy,'' said Mrs. Abshire. ``I know of someone who had to do that. God didn't set me down here to judge her. Who am I to judge her when I know what Tay-Sachs did to me and my husband, what we went through?''

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Discover New Underwater Volcanoes
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT - time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A series of underwater volcanoes has begun rising from the sea floor off the coast of Oregon, researchers said Sunday. The volcanoes have appeared during the past 10 years, forming a line about 300 miles off the coast, according to Dr. Robert Embley of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory. Several of the volcanoes are more than 100 feet high and a half-mile wide, according to Embly and researchers from Oregon State University. Embley said the appearance of the underwater volcanoes may be related to gigantic bursts of hot, mineral-rich water discovered in the same area in 1986 and 1987 during research on the sea floor. This is the first time scientists have been able to determine the date of particular ocean floor volcanoes, according to Embley. Monitoring the development may allow them to learn more about how such events affect ocean chemistry and temperature. The cones were discovered when sea floor pictures and surveys made during the last year were compared with 1981 surveys and several new volcanoes were found. Researchers then dove into the area in the submersible Alvin and found that fresh lava flows extend into and cover a large fracture that had cracked the older sea floor. The researchers believe that the sea floor in the area is actively spreading, producing increased volcanic activity. This region is part of the so-called Ring of Fire, a system of volcanic and earthquake-prone regions than encircle the Pacific Ocean, caused by movement of the giant plates that make up the surface of the Earth. It is here that the Pacific Plate is grinding against the North American plate, the same activity that helps provoke earthquakes in California and Alaska and volcanic eruptions such as that of Mount St. Helens. While the development of volcanoes under the ocean is not thought to be unusual, scientists do not really know how often such eruptions occur because of limited ability to monitor their development.

DOC.HEAD: Child, Grandmother Survive Being Run Over by Wheat Planter
DOC.TEXT: A woman threw herself over her 2-year-old granddaughter just as a 1-ton wheat planter rolled over them, and each somehow survived the twisting blades. ``She just lay down on her,'' said the child's mother, Karrie Sullivan. ``I don't think my daughter would be here today if she had not done that.'' JoanSullivan, 54, of Niles, was hospitalized for treatment of broken bones and bruises. Young Sara escaped Friday's accident with just a few scrapes. ``She saved her life, basically,'' Karrie Sullivan said. ``And Joan could have been a lot worse. I just can't believe it.'' The accident occurred while Sara's grandfather, James Sullivan, was planting wheat on the 800-acre family farm in Niles, about 20 miles east of Salina. Sara dashed between the tractor and the planting bins it was dragging and her grandmother went after her. Her grandfather didn't see or hear either of them as he drove the tractor. ``The wheat drills (discs) just ran over the top of her and chopped her up pretty bad,'' said Joan's cousin, Peter Sullivan. ``It kind of buried them in the ground a little bit, you know.'' A wheat planter, called a drill, hooks behind a tractor and plants seed in grooves cut by sharp-edged discs about a foot in diameter. The discs are about eight inches apart and are followed by rollers that compact the seed into the soil. No one could say why Joan and Sara Sullivan were not injured more seriously. Peter Sullivan speculated that because the field was tilled for sowing, the softer earth cushioned the victims. He also said the discs have a spring system that allows them to give slightly when they hit a large object.

DOC.HEAD: Populist Party Gains In Parliamentary Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with official preliminary results, likelihood of new coalition, quotes; trims; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The populist Freedom Party, capitalizing on widespread popular discontent over bureaucracy and corruption, made strong gains in parliamentary elections Sunday. The governing Socialists slightly increased their representation and offered to form a new coalition government with the conservative People's Party, which lost ground in the balloting. The Socialists made it clear throughout the election campaign they would not form a coalition with the Freedom Party, which they say is too far right. Preliminary results announced by Interior Minister Franz Loeschnak showed the Freedom Party increased its representation from 18 to 33 seats in the 183-seat Parliament and won 17 percent of the vote, up from 10 percent in 1986. The Socialist Party added one seat and now holds 81. The big loser was the People's Party, which has been in a coalition with the Socialists since 1986. It lost 17 of its 77 seats, its worst defeat in history. The fourth major party, the Green Alternative, won nine seats, an increase of one. Freedom Party leader Joerg Haider appealed to nationalist sentiments and voters seeking a change after 45 uninterrupted years of rule by either the Socialists or the People's Party. He hammered away at the special advantages members of the two big parties enjoy and attacked the relatively liberal treatment given immigrants from neighboring East European countries. The charismatic 40-year-old had said he hoped his party could win between 25-30 seats with its campaign against bureaucracy and high-level mismanagement. At least three corruption cases are pending against prominent Socialists. ``The 30 seats in parliament were our admittedly ambitious target,'' said Heide Schmidt, general secretary of the Freedom Party. ``The fact that we may achieve this or gain even more fills me with gratification.'' Helmut Kukacka, the People's Party general secretary, called it a ``heavy, depressing defeat.'' ``We are certainly the big losers,'' he said. The Conservatives still bear the burden of their support four years ago for President Kurt Waldheim, who is accused of concealing his World War II past. Waldheim was not considered a major issue in this campaign, however. The Socialists said their showing was a vote for Chancellor Franz Vranitsky, by far the most popular politician in Austria. Party chief secretary Josef Cap said the result would underscore the Socialists' claim to leadership. Vranitzky said he would invite the People's Party for coalition talks. But he added, ``it must be clear that the formation of a government cannot retroactively correct the election results,'' indicating a reduced role for the conservatives. Only 83 percent of the 5.6 million Austrians registered to vote went to the polls, one of the lowest turnouts in national elections. In 1986, 90 percent of the voters participated. There were few clear-cut issues in what was generally regarded as among the most uninspring election campaigns in years. The main topics were Austrian efforts to win membership in the European Community, calls by the right to limit immigration and foreign labor and mutual pledges to reduce privileges of officials who hold two or more paid jobs. Many observers said that with the likelihood the coalition would continue after the election, leaders of the major parties refrained from sharply attacking each other. Vranitzky, 53, has been working with his party to recover from stinging publicity caused by several party officials who tampered with public funds. In the scandal, Socialist Chancellor Fred Sinowatz was recently found guilty of perjury.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Hopeful Captive Dolphins Will Adapt to Wild
DOC.TEXT: Echo and Misha, two dolphins held captive for more than two years as part of a California research project, splashed to freedom in the same shallow waters they once knew as their home. ``When they start swimming along the coast and socializing with other dolphins - then we'll call it a success,'' said conservation biologist Randy Wells, who plans to track the dolphins for a year in what scientists say is the first extensive study of how captive dolphins adapt in the wild. ``Of course, it will take them a while to get their bearings,'' Wells said. Within seconds after a dozen Mote Marine Laboratory researchers gingerly lowered Echo and Misha into the water Saturday, they sped off in tandem - and beached themselves on a sandbar. Cheers turned to concern, and researchers swam out to the foundering dolphins and gave them a second push. Within an hour, they were spotted swimming with a pod of about three dolphins. Wells, affiliated with the Chicago Zoological Society, took the dolphins from the same harbor in the summer of 1988 for a project at the University of California at Santa Cruz. He wanted to study the sophisticated system of sounds dolphins use to gather information about their watery environment. Last month, the two 300-pound dolphins were transported to Mote on Central Florida's Gulf Coast to prepare for their return home. While other captive dolphins have been released in the wild, Wells said this is the first project involving electronic monitoring and tracking to find out how captive dolphins readjust and socialize. ``You have to understand that for the past two years, these dolphins have been isolated and hand-fed nothing but frozen fish,'' said Kerri Dieffenwierth, spokeswoman for Mote, where the dolphins were held in a protective lagoon, taught to eat live fish and slowly weaned from human contact. For the first two days in the wild, the 8- and 9-year-old males will be followed around the clock, both visually and with the help of a coin-sized radio transmitter on Echo's dorsal fin. ``Male dolphins tend to bond for life,'' the spokeswoman said. ``they were together when we found them and they should be together forever.'' The transmitter has a range of more than six miles and an expected life of two weeks before the specially designed bolts dissolve and fall off. After that and for the year to come, researchers working from a small boat will track the dolphins three to four days a week and for up to 12 hours a day - taking photographs to see how well they are assimilating into dolphin society and even counting their breaths to gauge their health. If they begin to show signs of sickness or are shunned by other dolphins, scientists are prepared to take them back. But Wells doesn't expect that to happen.

DOC.HEAD: Oil-Spill Equipment to be Auctioned
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of surplus cotton overalls, rubber gloves, fishing nets and other Exxon Corp. equipment left over from its oil-spill cleanup in Prince William Sound go on the auction block this week. ``You know, all of Alaska is going to be dressed up just like Exxon,'' said Bill Ballard, one of dozens of potential bidders scrutinizing the equipment laid out in warehouses and construction yards in south Anchorage. The auction begins Tuesday and is expected to last until Friday. Among items on sale will be 10,000 new cotton overalls, 10,000 disposable coveralls, 20,000 new rubber gloves, 3,000 pairs of new rain jackets and pants and 40 pairs of brand-new, size-13 rubber boots. The equipment ranges from inflatable rafts to portable toilets, and fishing nets to 50 miles of chain. The Exxon Valdez tanker ran aground on Prince William Sound in March 1989, spilling almost 11 million gallons of Alaskan crude in the nation's biggest oil spill. Exxon said last month it had sold the surplus gear to Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers International of Vancouver, British Columbia, for an undisclosed amount. The sale of 4,844 lots is open to all comers, with no minimum bids and a pledge that every item will be sold, the auctioneers said. Spokesman Rob Mackay said he expects at least 5,000 bidders will sign up, and that the auction will bring in more than $10 million in sales. Exxon spokesman Karsten Rodvik said the surplus is part of the 33,000 tons of cleanup equipment moved to Anchorage last fall for storage. ``We are keeping enough equipment and material to conduct a shoreline survey in the spring and to complete an additional cleanup that might be needed next year,'' he said. Though the sale will include some heavy equipment, specialized oil-spill gear like skimmers and booms are not being sold. They will be kept by Exxon for its refineries and marine terminals, Rodvik said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Says Abortion, Homosexuality Are `Spiritually Dangerous'
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church leaders on Sunday decried abortion, homosexuality and drug addiction as ``morally and spiritually dangerous'' lifestyles. ``In or out of marriage, abortion is not an individual choice. At a minimum, the lives of three are involved,'' Elder Boyd K. Packer told the church's 160th Semiannual General Conference. Only in cases of incest, rape, when a mother's health is jeopardized or a severely deformed fetus who cannot survive birth is abortion anything but a ``thou shalt not,'' Packer said, and even then ``much sober prayer is required to make the right choice.'' The two-day conference of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints concluded Sunday with the faith's president, Ezra Taft Benson, still hospitalized in serious condition following surgery nearly three weeks ago for blood clots on the brain. Church officials said Benson, 91, watched the proceedings on television. Packer, a senior member of the Council of the Twelve Apostles, blasted those who justify homosexuality by saying ``these impulses are inborn, cannot be overcome and should not be resisted.'' ``They quote scriptures to justify perverted acts between consenting adults. That same logic would justify incest or the molesting of little children of either gender,'' he said. ``I believe that most people are drawn to a life of drug addiction or perversion or submit to an abortion without really realizing how morally and spiritually dangerous they are.'' Elder Joseph B. Wirthlin of the Twelve warned against getting sidetracked by ``activities that begin innocently or that are perfectly legitimate in moderation, but in excess they can cause us to veer from the straight and narrow path to our destruction.'' Among those, he said, are excessive viewing of sports, television, improper movies and devotion to obtaining material possessions such as homes that are larger than necessary. ``And even if we are blessed enough to afford such luxury, we may be misdirecting resources that could be used better to build the kingdom of God, or to feed and clothe our needy brothers and sisters,'' Wirthlin said. Gordon B. Hinckley, Benson's first counselor in the governing First Presidency, lamented that the 7.5 million-member church likely would never shed its nickname, the Mormon Church, in favor of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. ``Because of the shortness of the word Mormon and the ease with which it is spoken and written, they will continue to call us the Mormons, the Mormon Church, and so forth,'' Hinckley said. ``They could do worse.''

DOC.HEAD: Dutch World War II Resistance Figure Dies At 82
DOC.TEXT: Johan Teengs Gerritsen, a well-known Dutch resistance fighter during World War II, died in a car crash Sunday at age 82, Dutch television reported. Teengs Gerritsen fought the German occupation of the Netherlands in 1940. He was captured and held at a concentration camp in France and later in Dachau, Germany, where he was freed by U.S. troops in 1945. In the 1970s, he became a spokesman for Dutch resistance fighters who opposed moves to pardon two German war criminals responsible for deporting more than 100,000 Dutch Jews. But Teengs Gerritsen eventually relented and supported the government's decision last year to free the Nazis, Ferdinand aus der Fuenten and Franz Fischer. The two have died since in their German homes.

DOC.HEAD: Duke Concedes Loss, Johnston Says He `Got the Message'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Under Louisiana's...' to change `unique' to `unusual' to reflect that at least two other states have open primaries.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU4
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. David Duke conceded defeat Sunday to incumbent U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, who said he ``got the message'' from 600,000 voters who backed Duke, a former Klan leader running as a Republican. Duke backed off his threat to file a lawsuit over absentee ballots cast - but not counted - for state Sen. Ben Bagert, the official Republican nominee. Bagert dropped out two days before Saturday's primary amid pressure from national GOP leaders who feared his presence in the race would help Duke force a November runoff. ``We'll help people who feel their right to vote has been abrogated,'' Duke said. ``We'll help them pursue that if they so desire, but I'm trying to do as Bennett Johnston said, and kind of heal at this point.'' Complete but unofficial returns gave Johnston 749,552 votes, or 54 percent, and Duke 605,681 votes, or 44 percent. Two minor Democratic candidates split the remainder. Nick Accardo had 21,709 votes and Larry Crowe had 14,472 votes. Duke's strength surprised pollsters, as he carried 23 of the state's 64 parishes and held Johnston close in several others. Duke had campaigned on a ticket that opposed affirmative action and proposed welfare reform and a flat-rate federal income tax. Johnston said Duke benefited from a protest vote arising from sour economic conditions in Louisiana. ``A lot of those votes were protest votes,'' Johnston said. ``People were sort of venting their spleen. They said, `Well, I'm going to send old Bennett a message.' Bennett got the message.'' He said he would work to diversify the state's economy away from the petroleum industry's boom-and-bust cycles. Under Louisiana's unusual open primary system, all candidates run against each other in the primary, regardless of party. A runoff would have been held Nov. 6 if Johnston had failed to receive a majority Saturday. Bagert withdrew too late to get his name off the ballot. Under a 1981 law, Bagert's votes could not be counted. Some were, however, because it was too late to change computer programs or courthouse operations. Those reported to the Associated Press gave Bagert 10,536 votes - less than 1 percent of the 1.4 million cast. Duke said ``political deals'' were responsible for Bagert's withdrawal. Johnston drew the unprecedented cross-party endorsement of eight Senate Republicans and Jack Kemp, secretary of housing and urban development. Johnston said his 10 percent victory margin would have been considered a landslide had it not been for Duke's presence in the race. ``When you can win at a time that incumbents all over the country are in trouble, when Louisiana has been in a depression and when people are trying to send a message ... I think that's a tremendous win,'' Johnston said. Duke said he was studying a possible run for governor in 1991. Such a race would require him to give up his state House seat, which he won in a special election in 1989. There also has been speculation Duke might seek a U.S. House seat in 1992, probably from one of the north Louisiana districts that gave him strong support Saturday. Johnston said Duke's political future was limited and predicted he would never win a statewide race or capture a U.S. House seat. Ed Renwick, a political pollster for Loyola University, said it would be difficult to discount Duke in future races because he drew 55 to 60 percent of the white vote. He said Duke's support on Saturday was threefold - voters opposed to Johnston, voters who merely wished to ``send a message'' and full-fledged Duke supporters. ``I think he'll keep the third group,'' Renwick said. ``He'll lose the first group. The question is how long he'll keep the second group.'' In other races on Saturday's ballot, New Orleans was assured of having its first black congressman since Reconstruction when state Sen. William Jefferson and Marc Morial, both Democrats, led a field of 12 to replace retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs. Jefferson and Morial meet in the runoff next month. By a 2-1 ratio, voters also approved Louisiana's first lottery since a corrupt private lottery was shut down by Congress in the late 1890s. Under a bill already approved by the Legislature, the games will be managed by a quasi-governmental corporation. New Orleans District Attorney Harry Connick, acquitted earlier this year of federal charges stemming from the return of a bookmaker's records, easily won re-election over two opponents. Connick is the father of Harry Connick Jr., a Grammy Award-winning musician.

DOC.HEAD: Like Winter in the Rockies, Summer in New England
DOC.TEXT: While a winterlike storm Sunday brought snow to higher elevations of Wyoming, Utah and Colorado, unseasonably warm temperatures prevailed in the Northeast. In Colorado, overnight snowfall brought up to 9.5 inches at Red Feather Lakes and 6 inches to Virginia Dale and Rand. In northern Utah, 3 inches of snow was reported east of Heber City and 2 inches at Park City. There also was snow in mountains of southern and southeast Wyoming and the Laramie Valley, with more expected Monday. Up to 7 inches of snow blanketed Cheyenne, while Laramie Valley got up to 5 inches. Light snow was reported in western Nebraska, with Kimball receiving about 4 inches of snow overnight. Most of the Midwest was cold Sunday afternoon, with temperatures in the 30s in Oklahoma, Kansas and eastern Nebraska. But in the South, East and Far West, sunny skies and warm temperatures prevailed Sunday afternoon. Temperatures were in the 80s across the Gulf Coast and the southern Atlantic Coast states, with parts of South Texas topping 90 degrees. Temperatures warmed into the 70s and 80s from the central Atlantic Coast north to New England. The West saw similar readings, with temperatures into the 90s in the Southwest deserts. Cape Hatteras, N.C., set a record high for the date: 86 degrees. Isolated showers and thunderstorms appeared in the South and Southeast, with nearly 2 inches of rain Sunday in Jonesboro, Ark. Overnight rain was locally heavy from eastern Kansas through southern and central Illinois. St. Louis got 2.25 inches overnight. Several western cities set record low temperatures for the date Sunday: 24 degrees in Boise, Idaho; 24 degrees in Spokane, Wash.; 25 degrees in Yakima, Wash.; and 16 degrees in Williston, N.D. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Sunday was 8 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont.
