DOC.HEAD: Fisherwoman's Case Dangles Too Long, Charges Dropped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `But Marion...' to CORRECT that prosecutor isn't running for secretary of state.
DOC.TEXT: Beatrice B. Thomas' crime was to reel in an undersized bass and not throw it back. But the courts kept her dangling too long, and now she is off the hook. Twice the 64-year-old Thomas went to court intending to plead guilty to catching the 9{-inch-long largemouth bass at Eagle Creek Reservoir. She had been caught red-handed at the reservoir in June by a conservation officer with the Indiana Department of Natural Resources. Possessing a largemouth bass under 14 inches long is a misdemeanor punishable by up to 60 days in jail and a $500 fine. On her first appearance at Marion Municiapal Court, officials could not find any record of her case. When she showed up again, the paperwork was still not straightened out, and she was asked to return a third time. But Marion County Prosecutor Stephen Goldsmith decided Friday he has bigger fish to fry. ``I do not intend to prosecute that woman,'' he said. ``Anyone who comes downtown twice to plead guilty deserves a break.'' Thomas is not completely satisfied. ``They might dismiss the charges against me, but somebody else might come along and have to go through the same thing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Battle Rioters Near Lyon
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of youths set fire to cars and buildings, ransacked shops and hurled rocks at riot police Sunday following the death of a motorcyclist in a collision with a patrol car. Police used tear gas against the rioters, who rampaged for several hours through a large commercial area in Vaulx-en-Velin, a low-income suburb of 50,000 people near Lyon. Columns of smoke towered over the town center. Seven firemen, three journalists and an undetermined number of rioters were injured. Youths from low-rent housing projects in the town held police responsible for the death Saturday of Thomas Claudio, 21. Claudio, whose family emigrated from Spain, was a passenger on a motorcycle that reportedly was being pursued for a traffic violation.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Government Names New Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan government on Sunday named a new foreign minister and prime minister, official television reported. The General People's Congress named Ibrahim Muhammad al-Bishari foreign minister, replacing Jadallah Azzuz al-Talhi, who becomes secretary for strategic industries, Libyan television said. Abu Zayd Umar Durdah was named secretary of the General People's Committee, or prime minister, according to the television, monitored in London. He replaced Umar Mustafa al-Muntasir, who became secretary for economic planning. The post of prime minister is not a powerful one in Libya, which is ruled by Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Bureaucratic posts in Libya frequently change hands.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Spends Sunday at Camp David and Away From Budget Fray
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Deletes last three grafs prv to remove reference to possibility of scheduled Souter White House ceremony being canceled; the White House says it will go ahead as planned
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush spent much of the holiday weekend in his mountaintop retreat at Camp David, Md., 75 miles from the budget battle that left tourists locked out of the capital's most famous monuments. Left behind in the White House was a skeleton staff of ushers, butlers and maids, but a full complement of Secret Service and uniformed officers. In a concession to austerity, Bush eschewed his Marine One helicopter and made the trip up to the Catoctin Mountains by motorcade Saturday night. ``It's a lot less expensive to go by motorcade,'' said John Herrick, a White House press aide who accompanied the president. Before leaving for Camp David, Bush had vetoed a short-term spending measure that Congress passed Friday night. Without spending authority, a phased shutdown of non-essential government services began nationwide. With the House trying to work out another budget pact Sunday, Bush conferred by telephone from Camp David with White House chief of staff John Sununu and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. The two men were part of the troika of key administration aides who negotiated the deal soundly rejected by the House early Friday. Sununu, appearing on CNN's ``Newsmaker Sunday'' program, said the administration remained reluctant to raise income tax rates and still would prefer a package like the one that went down to defeat in the House. But Sununu said the aim now was to find a way to allow the congressional committees to ``get some of the rough edges off'' a deal. Roman Popadiuk, a deputy White House press secretary working from home, said the next step ``is up to the Hill. They're supposed to come up with a budget.'' Bush was at Camp David with Thomas ``Lud'' Ashley, a former Ohio congressman and Yale classmate who is now a banking industry executive. Barbara Bush planned to join her husband at Camp David later Sunday after flying down from the couple's oceanfront home at Kennebunkport, Maine. Bush himself had planned to spend the extended Columbus Day holiday weekend in Maine, but canceled that trip in light of the budgetary crisis. He attended a 9 a.m. private service at a Navy chapel at Camp David as he usually does during his frequent stays there. Camp David is located within a 10,000-acre preserve known as the Catoctin Mountain Park and the adjacent Cunningham Falls State Park. Like other national parks, Catoctin Mountain Park was among the first to feel the budget pinch, with its visitor center closed and nature hikes and other interpretive programs canceled. Camp David itself, however, is a Navy installation, staffed permanently by Navy personnel and Marine guards, and its recreational facilities were not subject to the shutdown. Bush tentatively planned to return to the White House by motorcade Monday, again passing up the speedier but costlier helicopter ride, Herrick said. The White House normally is closed to public tours on Sunday. Officials said earlier that 65 of the 383 people who usually work there were deemed essential, including the National Security Council staff that operates the situation room 24 hours a day. But the staff that operates the executive mansion's living quarters - butlers, maids, chefs and others - was cut from 70 to 10.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Says Indian-Trained Agents Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan's army-backed caretaker government said Sunday it had arrested 58 agents who slipped into Sind, home province of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, to sabotage Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. A government spokesman said several of the agents confessed to having been sent by the Indian government and others claimed membership in the militant Al-Zulfikar organization, named for Ms. Bhutto's father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was overthrown in a 1977 coup and was hanged two years later for his alleged complicity in a murder plot. Army Chief-of-Staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg warned last week that India was hatching a plot to wreck Pakistan's elections. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since independence in 1947. Tensions have risen recently over a Moslem separatist movement in India-controlled Kashmir. ``If they can undermine the elections . . . Pakistan can be destabilized,'' said a government official, speaking of India. The official and the government spokesman spoke on condition of anonymity. Al-Zulfikar was run by Ms. Bhutto's younger brother, Murtaza, who has been living in Syria since he orchestrated the 1982 hijacking of a Pakistan International Airline aircraft. Pakistan's newspapers carried many stories over the past week about election sabotage plots, fuelling fears that polls could be postponed. Several analysts said an upsurge in Ms. Bhutto's popularity since her dismissal by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan on Aug. 6 may be worrying those who fired her. An Indian Embassy spokesman in Islamabad said he knew nothing of Indian nationals being arrested. ``Normally if there were Indians arrested the Foreign Office would be obliged to call us,'' he said, speaking on condition of not being further identified. The president dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government on charges of unchecked corruption and abuse of power. The dismissal probably was approved by the nation's powerful military, which has ruled Pakistan for 25 years of its 43 years as a nation. There is little love lost between the Bhutto family and the Pakistani military. Even Ms. Bhutto's critics concede that her popularity has soared since Ishaq Khan announced that special one-judge tribunals would investigate her goverment for corruption. The tribunals have been assailed as overtly partisan. They have indicted Ms. Bhutto; her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, and about six former Cabinet ministers. If convicted Ms. Bhutto could be barred from politics for up to seven years. She could be tried separately on criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Refugees Gather at Saudi Border after Iraq Opens Frontier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Arafat comments, picks up 11th graf pvs, `Kuwaiti refugees ...
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Kuwaitis crossed into Saudi Arabia on Sunday after Iraq suddenly relaxed restrictions on Kuwaitis leaving the occupied emirate. Some refugees said it was the latest move in an Iraqi campaign to depopulate Kuwait, isolate the resistance movement and prepare for war. World leaders kept up diplomatic efforts to achieve a peaceful solution to the crisis that arose with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu traveled to Oman after a two-day visit with King Faud in Saudi Arabia. PLO leader Yasser Arafat met King Hussein in Jordan and said a peace initiative on the gulf crisis was being formulated according to the plan proposed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. On Aug. 12, Saddam said he would discuss withdrawing from Kuwait if the Israelis also withdrew from the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Arafat said Saddam's proposal ``has brought aboutan international consensus for the need to solve the Palestinian problem.'' ``The linkage is becoming possible now. Those who believe otherwise, let them submit their own proposals to solve the Middle East problems,'' he said. Egyptian Foreign Minister Ismat Abdul-Maguid, meanwhile, arrived in Damascus for talks with Syrian President Hafez Assad. He indicated he was making the visit to increase cooperation in forcing Iraq out of Kuwait. Kaifu arrived in the Mideast last week to offer financial help to front-line states Turkey, Jordan and Egypt and to seek a political solution. He has referred to a new world order after the crisis is solved in which Japan was eager to play a role. Kaifu spokesman Shigeo Takaneka said Fahd urged Tokyo to spread its financial aid to other nations hit by the U.N.-imposed economic blockade of Iraq, such as Syria and Bangladesh. Takaneka said Japan reiterated its call for Iraq's complete and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, restoration of the emirate's leadership and release of all foreigners detained by Iraq after its attack on Kuwait. Kuwaiti refugees at the Khafji border crossing in Saudi Arabia said the border opened on Friday following intensified night searches in Kuwait City which prompted many of them to leave out of fear. They said Iraqi troops were confiscating all identification papers in Kuwait. That raised Saudi fears that the Iraqis planned to try to infiltrate agents into the kingdom. About 1,000 people arrived from Kuwait over the weekend, most lacking any identification, Saudi border officials said. The influx was the largest since mid-September, when 7,000 Kuwaitis poured through in a three-day frenzy. U.S. military officials in Washington and Saudi Arabia meanwhile reported the American troop buildup in the crisis area was nearly complete, with almost 200,000 U.S. soldiers deployed there. U.S. troops lead a multinational force arrayed in the Saudi desert to forestall any further Iraqi military thrust. Iraq controls 20 percent of world oil reserves with its takeover of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia, which adjoins Kuwait, is the world's biggest oil exporter. In other developments: -Soldiers in Israel began handing out gas masks to civilians in a nationwide drive to guard Israelis from a possible Iraqi chemical arms attack. Military officials called it just a preventive measure. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said in a speech Israel ``has no intentions to attack Iraq,'' although it takes Baghdad's chemical attack threats seriously, Israel radio said. -The British newspaper Independent identified a Chinese company it said supplied Iraq with a rare chemical used to make nuclear weapons, missile fuel and nerve gas. It said the China Wanbao Engineering Co. contracted to supply seven tons of lithium hydride to Iraq, breaching the U.N. embargo. Beijing officials last week strongly denied an earlier report about a chemical deal. -About 100,000 Italians joined a 15-mile peace march from Perugia to Assisi in northern Italy, many demanding that force not be used in the crisis. -Britain's visiting armed forces minister, Archibald Hamilton, said in Bahrain that Britain is redeploying a squadron of Tornado GR1 ground-attack jets from Bahrain to Saudi Arabia and 12 Jaguar strike aircraft from Oman to Bahrain. ``This is basically to enhance our deterrent effect,'' he said. -Kuwait Airways has started chartering flights from Cairo to take home thousands of Sri Lankan refugees transported from camps in Jordan, an airline officer said in the Egyptian capital. The airline, national carrier of Kuwait, has been out of operation since the invasion. A flight Saturday which carried about 376 Sri Lankans home was its first in more than two months. -The European Community nations discussed a military solution to the crisis but concluded it was better to see if the world trade embargo forces Iraq to leave Kuwait. ``Time is not in favor of Saddam Hussein,'' Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis told reporters at the meeting in Venice, Italy. -The Dutch government said its ambassador in Kuwait was expected to leave for Baghdad, effectively closing the mission because of unbearable conditions caused by Iraqi pressure. Foreign Ministry spokesman Dig Istha said the Belgian and German embassies are also likely to close soon.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery's Crew Starts Fire Aboard Shuttle as Test
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Kathy Thornton...' to CORRECT time element.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's astronauts, their primary job behind them, started a small fire aboard the shuttle Sunday as part of an experiment to study the spread of flames in space. The solar probe Ulysses, meanwhile, sped safely toward Jupiter at a record-setting 34,130 mph. Discovery's five-man crew started the satellite on its roundabout journey of 1.86 billion miles shortly after liftoff Saturday. The first test fire aboard a shuttle burned about 70 seconds within a sealed aluminum container, as cameras recorded the event. Shuttle safety managers wanted to observe how fire acts in the absence of Earth's gravity. The cylinder was filled with equal amounts of oxygen and nitrogen. The amount of gases will vary when the experiment is repeated on future flights. Discovery's five-member crew arose shortly before 3 a.m. EDT for its first full day in space Sunday. The astronauts are scheduled to stay in orbit until a Wednesday morning landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Saturday's launch marked the end of months of frustration for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which has suffered through problems with its shuttle fleet and the flawed Hubble Space Telescope. Columbia and Atlantis have been grounded since early summer by hydrogen leaks. Discovery's smooth liftoff, NASA's first shuttle launch in nearly six months, was followed by successful deployment of the sun probe Ulysses. The $250 million European spacecraft is expected to arrive at Jupiter in February 1992. The powerful gravity pull of that giant planet will act like a slingshot, accelerating the probe to an even higher speed and sending it streaking back toward the sun. Kathy Thornton of Mission Control in Houston told crew members before they went to sleep Sunday that Ulysses was slightly cooler than expected but within its temperature limits. Ulysses is to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. It will be the first spacecraft to orbit over the solar poles. Preliminary data show Ulysses will spend 231 days above 71 degrees solar latitude, seven or eight days more than if Discovery had gone up Friday, the earliest possible launch date for the mission, Thornton said. NASA had to delay the launch for a day. ``This is another space first - a customer who's happy with a launch delay,'' Thornton told the pleased crew. Sunday's fire experiment ``was designed from the beginning knowing what we were doing'' and its design was carefully reviewed by safety experts, said Louis Ignaczak, the project's supervisor. Coincidentally, Discovery commander Richard N. Richards had a fire scare during his first space flight in August 1989. A short circuit sent smoke and sparks into the cabin of the shuttle Columbia; NASA said the crew was never in danger. ``We can never learn enough about fire safety, as far as I'm concerned, aboard the orbiter,'' Richards said before Discovery's flight. As part of another experiment Sunday, the astronauts extended Discovery's 50-foot-long robot arm. Attached to the boom are two patches of material identical to that used on solar panels of a communications satellite stranded in a uselessly low orbit. Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the satellite, wants to measure how much the same kind of material on the satellite will decay in space before NASA sends up astronauts in early 1992 to repair the craft. ``Provided the results from this experiment are not wildly different from what we expect, it will be the final piece of data that gives us the confidence to go ahead and rescue the spacecraft,'' said Intelsat scientist Andrew Dunnet. The $157 million satellite failed to separate properly from an unmanned Titan rocket in March. Intelsat is suing rocket maker Martin Marietta Corp. for at least $400 million in damages. Earlier Sunday, astronauts Bill Shepherd and Bruce Melnick reported only limited success with an experiment to control TV cameras with voice commands. Their voices were recorded prior to the mission onto computer chips that the system was supposed to recognize in space. The system is designed to free astronauts of manual camera operations and thus let them to do more than one thing at a time. Shepherd and Melnick tried moving the cameras by speaking such words as ``up,'' ``down'' and ``zoom out.'' Melnick had better luck than Shepherd, who reprogrammed the system with the sound of his voice in space but still achieved little success. The two planned to repeat the experiment Monday and again Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, UAW Reach Tentative Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with details of deal, CORRECT number of locals to 44 sted 79. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `About 100,000... A version also moving on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union and Ford Motor Co. reached a tentative national labor contract Sunday closely mirroring the agreement last month with General Motors Corp. ``This tentative agreement provides that UAW-represented Ford workers will fully share in the gains achieved by the pattern settlement reached earlier at General Motors,'' said UAW President Owen Bieber in a statement. Under the three-year deal, Ford will put aside about $1.5 billion to cover the income of workers who are laid off, Bieber said. GM, which has three times as many UAW workers, promised to spend up to $4 billion to protect the incomes of laid-off workers. Negotiators stayed up all Saturday night to close the deal. As the negotiations intensified last week, after the union's contract with GM was ratified, the main dispute was a clause calling for penalty pay up to $5 an hour for excessive scheduled overtime. That provision in the GM-UAW contract was aimed directly at Ford. Since the late 1980s, Ford's manufacturing employees worked considerably more overtime than those at GM. At one time, nearly 20 percent of the cars and trucks the automaker assembled were made by workers on overtime. Ford Chairman Harold Poling said he did not expect the overtime penalty to be an immediate problem because of the falloff in truck and car sales. ``I think short term we're going to be faced a serious problem because of the general economy,'' Poling said. ``I think it's going to take some time to evaluate what the alternatives are.'' Analysts and automakers have forecast a slow recovery in the sales rate of cars and trucks in the United States from a trough late last year. Ford ``probably won't have much in overtime expenditures next year,'' auto analyst David Healy of the New York investment banker Barclays de Zoete Wedd said Sunday. The union has scheduled a meeting of its 135-member Ford bargaining council for Tuesday in Dearborn. That panel of union local presidents and bargaining committee officials must approve the tentative agreement before it is sent to the UAW's 44 Ford locals for rank-and-file ratification. About 100,000 Ford employees are covered by the UAW national contract. GM has about 300,000 workers represented by the union, and Chrysler Corp., which still must bargain a national agreement, has about 63,000 hourly and salaried UAW members. Provisions of the pattern agreement included: - A three-year income guarantee for every worker laid off for more than 36 weeks at factories closed because of slow car, truck or parts sales. - A 3 percent boost in workers' base wages in the first year and lump-sum payments of 3 percent of wages in the second and third years. - Continuation of cost-of-living adjustments in wages. - Improvements in pension payments. - No change in health-care provisions. The GM-UAW agreement was ratified a week ago in a lopsided 80 percent to 20 percent vote. After a contract with Ford is ratified, the UAW will head to Chrysler. There, the union and the company are at loggerheads over whether the financially struggling company will be allowed to deviate greatly from the pattern agreement. Company officials have insisted that Chrysler needs relief from soaring health-care costs, and the pattern agreement first negotiated with GM provides no changes.

DOC.HEAD: Dubai Ruler Dies at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to show discrepancies on Sheik Rashid's age; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Sheik Rashid..
DOC.TEXT: Sheik Rashid bin Saeed al-Maktoum, co-founder of the United Arab Emirates and ruler of Dubai, died Sunday, the state television announced. Official sources put Sheik Rashid's age at 84, but The International Who's Who, a reference book, said he was born in 1914, which would make him 75 or 76. The sources said Sheik Rashid died of old age after being near death for about four years. The official cause of his illness was not disclosed. Sheik Rashid was also vice president and prime minister of the U.A.E., the federation of sheikdoms that includes Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Sharjah, Ras al-Kaimah, Ajman, Umm al-Qaiwain, and Fujairah. Sheik Rashid founded the federation in 1971 with his brother-in-law, Sheik Zayed. The seven sheikdoms that stretch from Qatar to Oman along the Persian Gulf previously had been ruled together under an agreement with the B`itish. Sheik Rashid is survived by four sons. The eldest is Crown Prince Sheik Maktoum bin Rashid al-Maktoum, who is to succeed his father as ruler of the oil-rich emirate. Another son, Sheik Mohammed al-Rashid, is the U.A.E. defense minister, while Sheik Hamdan al-Rashid is minister of finance and industry. The president of the federation of gulf states, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan, is the late sheik's brother-in-law. Dubai, with a population of 400,000, mostly expatriate workers, produces a daily average of 500,000 barrels of oil. It is the leading business center in the Gulf region. Dubai has among the highest per capita incomes in the world - $19,300 a year. The federal government in Abu Dhabi declared a two-week period of mourning, and the burial was scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Israel ``Amazed'' over U.S. Travel Warning
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Israel expressed its ``amazement'' on Sunday at a State Department travel warning that urged Americans to avoid the Persian Gulf and Israeli-occupied lands because of persistent unrest and tensions. The advisory was issued Saturday. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir sought to reassure travelers Sunday, saying, ``All friends of Israel and those who know Israel also know you can visit Israel safely . . . without fear.'' Israel's embassy in Washington was instructed ``to express our amazement and complaint concerning the travel advisory which together with the situation in the Persian Gulf dealt with Judea, Samaria and Gaza,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud said. It said ``the Americans have recently expressed their satisfaction with the recent improvement of the conditions of security in the territories.'' Judea and Samaria are the biblical names for the occupied West Bank, which with the Gaza Strip was captured by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war. A Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule has been going on in these areas since December 1987. Tourism and hotel officials have reported a 30 percent drop in the number of visitors since the gulf crisis began. A nationwide gas mask distribution campaign has begun here in response to threats of chemical attack from Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Johnston: Duke Won't Last
With AM-Louisiana Primary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Unusually upbeat after an unsettling U.S. Senate race, J. Bennett Johnston said Sunday that David Duke's strong challenge would not shove him to the political right. Johnston said his 10-point victory over Duke would have been considered a landslide if his opponent had not been a former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon. ``When you can win at a time that incumbents all over the country are in trouble, when Louisiana has been in a depression and when people are trying to send a message ... I think that's a tremendous win,'' Johnston said. ``There's frustration out there,'' he said. ``When people are unemployed and underemployed, it's easy to blame it on someone else. It's easy to blame it on affirmative action.'' Johnston, a Democrat, captured a fourth term in Saturday's primary. Unofficial returns gave him 54 percent of the vote against 44 percent for Duke, who was running as a Republican on a platform that opposed affirmative action. During his third term, Johnston was linked with the liberal wing of the Senate with an unsuccessful bid to become Senate majority leader and his key role in opposing Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork. At the same time, he usually voted along conservative lines on such issues as defense. ``The left is not comfortable with him. The right is not comfortable with him,'' said Wayne Parent, a political scientist at Louisiana State University. Johnston said he ``got the message'' from voters who backed Duke. Asked whether the scare would move him more into the conservative ranks, he said: ``No. It's going to push me closer to the people, working harder for the people. That means doing even more than I've done.'' Johnston, chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, which oversees legislation dealing with the oil and gas industry, has drawn fire for accepting millions of dollars in campaign donations from political action committees, including the petroleum and petrochemical industries. Both industries have been blamed for contributing heavily to Louisiana's environmental problems. Until this race, Johnston had no problems winning re-election. Parent said Duke's showing probably would not affect Johnston's place in Washington. ``He'll be viewed as a senator who survived an odd race as many senators have,'' he said. Johnston pledged to work against Duke in any future race. Duke said Sunday that he is considering a run for governor next year. ``David Duke may have the Gestapo, but we've got the shock troops in our favor,'' Johnston said.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Says Oil Crisis Could Shake Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel said Sunday an energy crisis stemming from a drop in Soviet oil supplies could undermine Czechoslovakia's new democracy. Authorities began cutting back on gasoline sales Saturday because Moscow has not been meeting its quota of oil deliveries. Citizens can buy about seven gallons of gas a month at the official price of about $3. Purchases exceeding that cost more. Havel is seeking an urgent meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov to discuss the oil crisis. ``I would like to explain to Gorbachev the way we see things,'' Havel said in his regular weekly radio address. ``At this moment we are talking not only about business and dollars but about stability of a country in Central Europe, a country whose stability many other European countries believe in and depend on,'' Havel said. Czechoslovakia is introducing economic reforms designed to transform the centralized economy left behind by the ousted Communists to a market economy. Czechoslovak officials held talks with Soviet authorities last week in Moscow and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier raised the oil issue with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze during talks at the United Nations. Havel said the threat to Czechoslovakia's economy could have far-reaching negative consequences for the ``authority and prestige'' of the Soviet Union. Soviet authorities have said this year's supply of oil to Czechoslovakia will be about 2.6 million tons less than the original allotment of 16.6 million tons. Havel said he would emphasize in talks with Gorbachev ``that Czechoslovakia is making an effort in all talks dealing with the future of the Warsaw Pact and the new European peace initiative to respect sensitively the Soviet Union's interests.'' If agreements are broken, Czechoslovakia would not feel bound to take ``excessive consideration,'' he said. Havel said Prague is also looking elsewhere for oil supplies to end its near-total dependence on the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union was for years the main oil supplier, under subsidized conditions, for Czechoslovakia and other East European nations. However, next year it will begin demanding convertible currency for its oil.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Ignored Scientist's Call for Tests on Leaking Tank
DOC.TEXT: Officials at the Hanford nuclear reservation ignored a call to conduct tests on a leaking nuclear-waste storage tank, apparently because the procedure was too expensive, a retired Hanford scientist said. ``These are not inexpensive tests,'' soils expert Ronald Routson said in an interview reported Sunday in The Seattle Times. ``I think it was dollars, pure and simple.'' Routson said he urged Hanford officials in 1978 to perform the tests after he noticed changes in radiation measurements in soil beneath the single-walled tank, which was damaged in a 1965 steam explosion. ``The only way to know what was going on at that tank was to do the tests and that wasn't done,'' said Routson, who retired last year after 23 years at Hanford. Rockwell International was the government's prime contractor at Hanford in south-central Washington until 1987. Ron Gerton, waste management director for the U.S. Department of Energy in Richland, said the agency is ``fairly confident this work wasn't done,'' but said he does not know why. Memos exchanged by Hanford contractors and its owner, the Department of Energy, indicate Tank 105A could have leaked more than a million gallons of contaminated cooling water into the desert soil from 1965 through 1978. Public documents initially estimated the leak at 5,000 gallons, but make no mention of cooling water that was regularly added to the tank until 1978 to prevent an explosion, the newspaper reported last week. The state Department of Ecology has asked the Department of Energy to provide all documentation about the 35-year-old tank by Wednesday, said Roger Stanley, manager of the state agency's Nuclear and Mixed Waste Program. Tank 105A is one of 177 at Hanford used to store waste generated during four decades of plutonium production for nuclear weapons. In a letter to Hanford managers dated April 12, 1978, Routson said changing radiation measurements in the soil beneath the concrete structure indicated ``a substantial quantity of the water being added to the tank is leaking to the sediment ... up to 570,000 gallons.'' He recommended tests to measure how much cooling water was leaking and how much was evaporating inside the tank, and sampling the sludge in the bottom of the tank to determine its radioactive content. ``I told my managers there were indications that radiation had leaked and they ought to find out what's going on,'' Routson said from his home in Benton City. Three radiation-detection devices buried beneath the tanks are inadequate to properly assess how much was leaking, he said. Spokesman Eric Campbell of Westinghouse Hanford, which replaced Rockwell as prime contractor at the site, said current records show that the radioactive leak has not spread more than 100 feet from the tank. Ground water lies 285 feet below the surface. Records before 1977 have not been found, Campbell said.

DOC.HEAD: Mysterious Alumnus Showers Professors with Goodies
DOC.TEXT: Whitworth College saluted a devoted alumnus this weekend, but nobody was surprised when the Mystery Man didn't show up for the festivities. Since 1988, the Seattle-area Mystery Man has sent dozens of professors and their spouses on exotic trips, all expenses paid, following up with gifts such as cameras, artwork or coffee makers. Alfred Gray, a retired Whitworth journalism professor, and his wife, Nicolin, were whisked off on a trip to New Zealand last fall. And three weeks ago, a local department store advised them ``we were supposed to come in and pick out a TV or sound system he wanted us to have,'' Gray said. So far, 28 current and former faculty members at the private school have been recipients of the Mystery Man's largesse and there seems to be no end in sight, said Paul Viren, director of Whitworth's development and alumni affairs office. Almost all the faculty contacts are made by Laurel Lindberg, the travel agent who arranges the trips. Lindberg also accepted the Whitworth College award for alumni devotion on the Mystery Man's behalf at Saturday's homecoming-weekend banquet. No one came forward when he was invited to accept the award in person, Viren said. Lindberg said the Mystery Man ``prefers to keep himself out of the picture,'' but he did give her a brief message to read. ``Your students have not forgotten you,'' she quoted him as saying. Campus sleuths have determined that the Mystery Man ``probably was here in the early to mid 60s,'' Viren said. He likely has spent more than $150,000 so far on the surprise gifts, the school official estimated. ``He is certainly not doing it for the publicity or for tax breaks. He must do it for the joy it gives him,'' Viren said.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Party Endorses Call for Taiwan Independence
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan's largest opposition party passed a resolution Sunday renouncing the country's claim over mainland China, and observers said the vote could lead to a backlash by the ruling Nationalist party. ``This party asserts our country's practical sovereignty does not extend to mainland China and outer Mongolia,'' said Huang Hsin-chieh, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party. Taiwan should plan its future based on its current territory, he said. Huang was speaking at the opposition party's congress at a hotel in Taoyuan, 31 miles west of Taipei. Some 170 delegates gave him a standing ovation. ``We are merely stating a political reality,'' Huang later told reporters. Huang said his party passed the resolution despite threats from the ruling Nationalist Party, whose secretary-general, James Soong, met opposition leaders on Saturday evening. Officials said the government would disband any political party that openly advocates Taiwan's existence as a state independent from mainland China. The Nationalists had agreed in July to political reforms reducing their four decades-long grip on the country. The reforms included allowing, at some time in the near future, the country's first popular vote for the presidency. Advocating an indepedent Taiwan is viewed as a seditious act by the Nationalist government, which fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces on mainland China. The Nationalists since then have limited the voting power of native Taiwanese, who make up about 80 percent of the population. Earlier on Sunday, President Lee Teng-hui chaired the inaugural session of the National Unification Council, a task force formed to assist the president in making policies on Taiwan's reunification with China. ``We have never abandoned the goal of regaining mainland territory and completing national unification,'' Lee said. Lu Ya-li, a political science professor at National Taiwan University, said the opposition party's statement could lead to repression by conservative Nationalists. ``The pace of democratic reforms will also slow down,'' he predicted.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Bond for Youth Charged in April Slayings of Couple
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `At an...' to CORRECT to hearing sted arraignment; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Biro's attorney...'
DOC.TEXT: A judge denied bond on Sunday for a 17-year-old high school student charged with killing a young suburban couple and their unborn child in a case that had stumped police for months. David J. Biro of Winnetka was being held at Cook County Jail on two counts of first-degree murder and one count of deliberately killing a fetus in the shooting deaths of Richard and Nancy Langert, who lived near him in the prosperous Chicago suburb. Biro's arrest Friday followed six months of a frustrating, multistate investigation in which police officers pursued numerous dead-end leads, including rumors that the killings might be linked to terrorist reprisals from Irish factions. At a hearing in Cook County Court, Judge Bernard Spak denied bond to Biro, who is being charged as an adult, according to Maureen McHale, a spokeswoman for the Cook County state's attorney office. Biro's attorney, Bob Gewirtz, said he told the judge he was upset that Biro was held in police custody for more than 24 hours before being formally charged Saturday evening. ``Apparently he had not been allowed to talk to anyone in his family or call an attorney during that whole time,'' Gewirtz said. Biro, a senior at New Trier High School, lives five blocks from the townhouse where the couple was shot to death in the basement on the evening of April 8. Mrs. Langert was 2{ months pregnant at the time of the shootings. Police have acknowledged that Biro and the couple knew each other, but prosecutors refused to elaborate on how well or what a possible motive for the killings might be. Police Chief Herbert Timm said Saturday that Biro and the victims were ``acquainted,'' but would not elaborate. Timm also said ``nothing in their (the victims') personal lives led to this tragedy.'' Evidence against Biro was collected at the crime scene and in his home, and police believe he acted alone, Timm said. The Chicago Sun-Times reported in its Sunday editions that Winnetka investigators focused on Biro after he told another youth details of the Langert slayings that had not been released publicly. Besides the murder charges, Biro is accused of burglary at his high school and of stealing a firearm. A preliminary hearing is scheduled for Tuesday. Langert, 30, and Mrs. Langert, 25, worked at Gloria Jean's Coffee Bean Corp., a suburban Arlington Heights-based chain of gourmet coffee shops. A spokesman for the company described them as ``kids you would want to be best friends with.'' The rumors of possible involvement of Irish factions stemmed from the fact that Mrs. Langert's sister is active in support for rights for the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: More Soviet Citizens Leave Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Soviet citizens left Iraq Sunday on a special Aeroflot flight, the first group to depart since President Saddam Hussein told an envoy from Moscow last week that they would be free to go. Soviet Embassy officials said more flights would be arranged to evacuate Soviet citizens who want to return home. At least 2,000 out of an estimated 5,000 have expressed that desire, the officials said. Saddam gave his personal permission for the evacuation on Friday when he met with Yevgeny Primakov, a top aide to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. More than 11,000 Soviets were in Iraq at the time of the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The last flight taking Soviets home, mostly women and children, was on Sept. 27. Many of the remaining 5,000 are oil industry technicians working under contract with the Iraqi government. The Soviet Union's Tass news agency reported earlier that Primakov had ``raised the issue of the departure from Iraq of Soviet specialists wishing to go home'' at the request of Gorbachev. The specialists were not among the foreigners held as ``human shields'' at hotels and strategic sites in an effort to deter attacks. Tass said Primakov told Saddam that Moscow ``favors a political settlement of the gulf crisis, bearing in mind a return to the situation that existed before Aug. 2.'' The Soviet envoy repeated Moscow's belief that Saddam should withdraw immediately from Kuwait, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Ultra-Rightist Party Holds First Meeting in Former East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The right-wing National Democratic Party on Sunday held its first rally in the former territory of East Germany and demanded that German borders be extended to their pre-World War II limits. The party, which is reported to have about 6,000 members in former West Germany, had been banned in Communist East Germany. About 700 police officers in riot gear were deployed against any clashes between the rightists and about 250 protesters, according to ADN, which before unification was the official East German news agency. ADN did not say how many people attended the meeting. Speakers said the unification of Germany last Wednesday should be a first step toward the return of territory forfeited by Germans after World War II, ADN reported. About one-third of present-day Poland was German territory before the war.

DOC.HEAD: Duke Boosted by Strong Showing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to fix category code.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Louisiana Primary, Bjt
LaserPhoto NU4
DOC.TEXT: It should have been the morning after but instead it seemed more like a new beginning for David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard and Nazi sympathizer. Duke surprised pollsters with a strong showing in the U.S. Senate race, and took time to outline a national agenda while conceding defeat Sunday. ``I've got to be very encouraged by this election,'' Duke said. ``I want to make a difference. And whether it's myself or other people out there, we've got to have people up front talking about the issues this campaign talked about.'' Campaigning against affirmative action, minority set-asides, busing for school integration and welfare abuse, Duke garnered 44 percent of the unofficial vote in Saturday's race against 54 percent for incumbent U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. ``You don't win elections with 44 percent, but it makes a lot of politicians sit up and take notice,'' said Edward Renwick of Loyola University's Institute of Politics. About 600,000 voters backed Duke, which represented a substantial widening in his political base in two years. In his first political victory in February 1989, Duke formally registered as a member of the Republican Party three days before he was elected to the Louisiana House. He won by just over 227 votes in a district that was 99.6 percent white. Running as a Democrat, Duke was defeated for state Senate in 1975 and 1979. In 1988, he got on the presidential ballot in 15 states as a Populist Party candidate, winning 48,267 votes, or 0.05 percent of the 91 million votes cast. The campaign was managed by a former leader of the American Nazi Party. As a student, Duke dressed in a Nazi uniform at a campus protest and later became national grand dragon of the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. Duke left the KKK in 1980 after being accused of selling a secret membership list. He formed the National Association of White People, and shared a telephone number with the KKK until reporters found out about it in 1989. Since winning election last year, Duke says he has moderated his stand. He described his former Klan affiliation as youthful hijinks. Duke said the Senate race was the first ``in recent history where affirmative actin became a major issue, where strong programs of welfare became a major issue. And I think now that's going to happen across the country.'' Duke said he was studying a possible run for governor in 1991. ``I certainly want to make an impact in state politics and I want to continue to make an impact in national politics,'' he said. ``We are committed that this cause will not cease here,'' he added. ``This is just the beginning, not the end of any political odyssey.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Calls Off Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Mozambique rebels has called off peace talks with Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano's government. Afonso Dhlakama, head of the Mozambique National Resistance, said on South African television Sunday the rebels would not take part in the talks because government soldiers, backed by troops from Zimbabwe, had started a new offensive against the rebels. The rebels have been battling Mozambique's government since 1977. They say they are seeking recognition as a political party and free elections. But the rebels' political goals have never been clear; they have been accused of widespread atrocities against civilians. Periodic peace talks have been held in Rome. There have been no breakthroughs, but more negotiations were expected. Zimbabwean troops have been assisting the Mozambique government for several years. Their primary aim is to help protect Mozambique's Beira corridor railroad, which is landlocked Zimbabwe's shortest route to the Indian Ocean. The Mozambican war has left the southeastern African country one of the poorest in the world. Annual per capita income is less than $200 and almost half the 15 million people require some food assistance. Chissano, a former Marxist, has been making political and economic reforms. Mozambique's parliament is debating a new constitution that would allow opposition parties to compete in elections next year.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein, Wilson Clash in Bitter Debate
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidates Dianne Feinstein and Pete Wilson clashed Sunday on Wilson's U.S. Senate attendance record, campaign funding and their visions for the state's future, in a bitter first debate. Feinstein, the Democratic former mayor of San Francisco, and Republican Wilson both claimed to be the candidate of new ideas. ``I think there's a need for someone that's fresh, new and a little bit different,'' Feinstein said in the live, televised debate. Wilson said that being a Republican would not handcuff him in Sacramento, where the Legislature is dominated by Democrats. He also portrayed himself as a reformer. ``I'm running for governor because I want to make changes in California that I think need to be made,'' said Wilson. He would give up his Senate seat if elected Nov. 6 to succeed retiring Republican Gov. George Deukmejian. The debate quickly turned to attacks, some personal. Feinstein accused Wilson of having ``the worst attendance record in the Congress,'' missing votes on the death penalty, Supreme Court confirmation, Middle East resolutions and the budget. ``I think absenteeism is an important indication of performance,'' said Feinstein. Wilson countered that he has a 93 percent attendance record overall, 2 percentage points better than that of Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Turning to the offensive, Wilson criticized Feinstein for taking large campaign donations in the wake of a judge's overturning Proposition 73, which had limited individual donations to $1,000. He singled out Feinstein's acceptance of $150,000 from a California Highway Patrol organization. ``Dianne, I am truly shocked that you would be so blind to so gross a conflict of interest,'' he said. The one-hour debate, televised from KNBC-TV's studios, marked the first time the rivals for governor have met face-to-face in eight months, and their first-ever televised showdown. A second and final televised debate is scheduled next week in San Francisco. The debate was divided into 30 minutes of questions from political reporters and 30 minutes in which Feinstein and Wilson questioned each other. The two debates are especially important because Wilson and Feinstein have been virtually tied in every independent poll reported since they won their party nominations in the June primary. Much of the debates' impact is expected to come in post-debate television and print reports. Viewership for the Sunday debate was not expected to be particularly high because it coincided with the second game of the American League baseball championship series between Oakland and Boston and a Los Angeles Raiders-Buffalo Bills football game. Next week's debate will compete with two of the most popular shows on television, ``The Cosby Show,'' and ``The Simpsons.''

DOC.HEAD: Miami Arms Broker Says He's Owed for Bomb Sale to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: A Florida arms brokr is suing to recover more than $30 million he claims is owed to him for arranging the sale of cluster bombs to Iraq. The timing, his lawyer admits, may be a little awkward. Nasser Beydoun, 47, of Coral Springs, said he masterminded a 1983 deal that enabled Chilean industrialist Carlos Cardoen to sell the Baghdad government at least $467 million worth of cluster bombs and other military equipment. In a lawsuit filed with the Circuit Court in Dade County, Beydoun claims Cardoen often referred to him as a ``golden key'' to the Middle East arms market. ``When I opened the market, he crossed the bridge and he burned it, leaving me behind,'' Beydoun said. Cardoen, 48, made a fortune selling bombs to Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran, The Miami Herald reported Saturday. Beydoun said he hooked up with Cardoen in 1982, when he was appointed the exclusive sales representative of Explosivos Cardoen Ltd. in Iraq, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia. In court papers, Beydoun claimed he gave up a lucrative food and cigarette exporting business to work for Cardoen, whose Cardoen Industries operates a weapons factory in Chile. Cardoen signed a ``letter of agreement and protection'' that authorized Beydoun to be his exclusive agent in Iraq, court papers say. Beydoun's job was to sell 500-pound cluster bombs to the Iraqi Air Force at $6,500 apiece. He was to receive $500 for each bomb sold. Beydoun said he spent $285,000 of his own money to fly back and forth to Baghdad. The Iraqis eventually agreed to buy 3,000 cluster bombs at $7,230 each, he said. Cardoen sent the bombs overseas aboard an Iraqi Airways jet from Santiago, or by ship out of the Chilean port of Iquique, Beydoun said in court papers. That sale put $21 million into Cardoen's bank accounts in Dade County and elsewhere, the lawsuit said. The Iraqis later purchased more bombs, a bomb factory and machinery, Beydoun claims in the suit. In all, Cardoen sold at least $467 million in war materials, the suit says. Beydoun claims he is owed commissions of $35.9 million, but has collected only $5.3 million. Beydoun's attorney, Hendrik Milne, said his client tried to settle the dispute this summer. Cardoen's lawyers have rejected the claims, Milne told The Miami Herald. With Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the buildup of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, a Florida jury might find it difficult to side with someone who supplied bombs that could be used against Americans, Milne said. ``It's not a popular case on either side,'' he said. On the other hand, he said, ``Who are they going to prefer? The bomb maker who kept all the money? Or the broker who should have been paid, and wasn't?''

DOC.HEAD: Moslems, Indian Security Forces Clash in Srinagar; 11 Killed
DOC.TEXT: Moslem militants and Indian security forces held running gun battles over a 12-hour period Sunday, leaving 11 dead, and fires allegedly set by militiamen destroyed 100 houses, news accounts said. The army was deployed in downtown Srinagar and the city administration imposed a curfew, according to the reports from the Press Trust and United News of India news agencies. Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir state, has been wracked since January by a Moslem movement for secession from Hindu-dominated India. Srinagar residents said Indian paramilitary troops set fire to a residential neighborhood in retaliation for an early morning ambush by the militants. The fire destroyed more than 100 wooden houses and spread to a downtown area. Security men ``came and threw gunpowder on my house and my window caught fire,'' resident Ghulam Rasson Gilkar said. Shouting and screams rose from the densely populated Cowdara neighborhood, about a mile from the city center, as residents loaded whatever they could on their backs and fled to safety through narrow alleyways. An Indian government spokesman in New Delhi denied soldiers set the blaze, which he said was caused by gunfire. The spokesman could not be identified under briefing regulations. Residents also told reporters that security forces had fired upon fire trucks that approached to douse the flames. United News of India said gun battles Sunday left nine civilians and two Indian soldiers dead. At least 12 people, including five soldiers, were injured, the agency said. Militants also tried to assassinate Izhar Alam, the second-ranking police officer in Kashmir. Their gunfire missed Alam but critically wounded two of his guards, the Press Trust reported. At least 1,340 people have died in political violence in Kashmir this year. Indian security forces have been accused of human rights violations in trying to suppress the militant movement.

DOC.HEAD: Two of Seven Kidnapped Colombian Journalists Sent Taped Message
DOC.TEXT: Two of the seven journalists being held hostage by the Medellin cocaine cartel sent their family members a tape-recorded message praying for a quick resolution to the crisis, local news media reported Sunday. It was the first word from any of the victims since they disappeared in September and August. ``We hope that this will end well and that we will be able to be with you soon,'' Diana Turbay de Uribe said in a message sent to her father, former President Julio Cesar Turbay. He was president for the Liberal Party from 1978 to 1982. The text, read by a national radio network, included statements by a second kidnapped journalist, Azucena Lievano. She said in a letter to her husband, ``We ask please that the prayers, which are the only things that reassure us, and the supplications you have made for us will permit us to regain our liberty in a short time.'' The two women said they were in good health. They did not mention the conditions of five other missing journalists. Nor did they give any information on who was holding them. Lievano, a national TV reporter, and Turbay, editor of a Colombian news magazine, were kidnapped with four other journalists on Aug. 30. Francisco Santos, managing editor of Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper, was abducted on Sept. 19. The administration of President Cesar Gaviria says the Medellin cartel is holding all seven journalists. The drug traffickers have made no ransom demands, but a recent cartel statement called for negotiations with the government toward achieving full amnesty for its members. Gaviria has rejected any negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Reportedly Hints at Return of Some Disputed Islands
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has indicated it may be willing to return two of four disputed islands to Japan to improve relations between the two countries, news reports said Sunday. Soviet officials made the proposal to a group of Japanese lawmakers who visited Moscow late last month, Japanese newspapers reported. The territorial dispute involves the southern Kuril islands, off northern Japan, which were seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. The dispute has prevented better ties between the two Pacific powers and kept them from signing a peace treaty officially ending wartime hostilities. The Soviet officials proposed to the Japanese delegation that the new agreement confirm a 1956 Japan-Soviet Joint Declaration. At the time, Moscow agreed to return Shikotan Island and the smaller Habomai island group, Kyodo News Service quoted Japanese officials as saying. The 1956 declaration cleared the way for a resumption of diplomatic relations. But when Japan signed a mutual security treaty with the United States in 1960, the Soviet Union declared it would only return the islands after all foreign troops were withdrawn from Japan. Japan has continued to demand that all four of the disputed islands in the southern Kurils be returned. The other islands are Kunashiri and Etorofu. The Soviet Union hopes that it can attract Japanese investment and high technology assistance by settling the territorial dispute. The nationally circulated newspaper Asahi Shimbun said Soviet officials hoped to conclude the new agreement when Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev visits Tokyo next spring. Asahi Shimbun said the proposed agreement calls for the countries to cooperate in seeking international stability and development; prepare for the conclusion of a peace treaty in three to five years; confirm the principles of the 1956 joint declaration; and increase economic cooperation and exchanges. Japanese government and party officials and Soviet Embassy officials were not available Sunday to discuss the reports.

DOC.HEAD: Klaus Weakens, Moves Over Open Atlantic Waters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Klaus now a tropical depression; picks up 7th graf, `Klaus, the...'
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus weakened into a depression and moved further into the open Atlantic Sunday after unleashing wind and rain that left at least six dead and 1,500 homeless in the northeastern Caribbean. Klaus briefly reached hurricane status Friday, but was downgraded to a tropical storm Saturday and then dropped to depression-level winds of 35 mph Sunday evening, forecasters said. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, the center of the depression was located at latitude 19.8 north and longitude 67.0 west, or about 105 miles northwest of San Juan, Puerto Rico. The depression was moving west-northwest at near 14 mph, and the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables said little change in strentgh or direction was expected through Monday. The hurricane center on Saturday lifted all storm warnings and watches for the northeastern Caribbean. By Sunday night, it said most Klaus-related showers were well east of any land. Klaus, the 11th named storm and the sixth hurricane of the Atlantic hurricane season, skirted Antigua on Friday, tearing roofs from houses but causing no major damage. The French island of Martinique south of the Leewards was by far the hardest hit. Heavy rain since Tuesday spawned landslides and serious flooding, forcing 1,500 people from their homes and killing six people, authorities said. Wind and flood damage also occurred on Barbados, Dominica and St. Lucia, where banana growers said about 15 percent of this year's crop was destroyed. They estimated damages at $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Echoes of the Gulf of Tonkin in the Persian Gulf Resolution
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: With incantations against the ghosts of an earlier crisis that became a war, Congress finally found a way to applaud President Bush for his current stand against Iraq - while avoiding commitments for the future. Now there are suggestions that there ought to be another resolution, telling Bush that Congress wants him to consult regularly with its leaders after it adjourns in about 10 days, to keep them informed on Middle East operations. But one refrain was repeated two dozen times, with minor variations, as the House and the Senate briefly debated and overwhelmingly approved the measures last week, two months after the fact. ``This resolution is not an authorization for the use of force now, or in the future,'' said Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader. ``This resolution is not a Gulf of Tonkin resolution.'' The 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution still haunts the Congress that adopted it in swift response to a reported attack at sea, then saw it cited by the White House as the equivalent of a declaration of war in Vietnam. ``As one who voted for the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, as everyone else in the House did, I many times have regretted that vote,'' said Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis., one of 25 House members serving then and now. He argued that no matter what is said about the limits of the Persian Gulf resolution, overwhelming approval could be read as unfettered congressional support for Bush in ``whatever policy he chooses to pursue.'' The House vote for the resolution was 380 to 29. The Senate approved it 96 to 3. The Democrats who run Congress had been trying for weeks to decide on a way to vote support for Bush's United Nations diplomacy and military deployment, without signing on for the duration. The congressional role in such situations always has been hard to define, especially in the era of undeclared wars. Congress has clear authority over military appropriations, but that comes after the fact of a quick strike or deployment. There is a system under the war powers resolution of 1973, but that never has worked. It requires that a president get approval from Congress within 90 days if he sends troops into situations in which hostilities are imminent. Bush got around it simply by reporting that hostilities are not imminent in the Middle East. ``We are operating today on the false premise that our troops in the Persian Gulf ... are not in imminent danger,'' said Sen. William S. Cohen, R-Maine. ``I simply do not accept that.'' Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., said Friday that Congress should invoke the war powers system by adopting a measure authorizing the Middle East troop deployment for another 90 days. That's not likely, and it would be subject to veto anyhow. ``The alternative is to go home, and come back, and find a battle, and then everybody's going to be up here talking about the Bush war,'' Hatfield said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., suggested the call for regular White House consultation with congressional leaders instead. He said Congress already had ``implicitly authorized what the president is doing'' with its resolutions earlier in the week. Those measures declare support for ``continued action by the president ... to deter Iraqi aggression and protect American lives and vital interests,'' stipulating that it must be in accordance with United Nations decisions, and with U.S. processes including congressional action to appropriate the funds. Mitchell said the Senate resolution was not an authorization ``for the use of force now, or in the future.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said the House vote ``does not support future actions except those actions that continue current policy.'' For all those caveats, there is no guarantee that current policy won't mean war. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, UAW Reach Tentative Contract
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AM version planned; press conference scheduled for 4 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers reached a tentative national labor contract early Sunday with Ford Motor Co. that apparently follows a pattern set in negotiations with General Motors Corp. Neither the union nor Ford gave details of the new contract. UAW President Owen Bieber, however, referred to similarities between the Ford and GM pacts. ``This tentative agreement provides that UAW-represented Ford workers will fully share in the gains achieved by the pattern settlement reached earlier at General Motors,'' Bieber said. Ford, which relies more heavily on overtime than GM and Chrysler Corp, was wary about a provision in the GM agreement that pays workers $5 an hour extra for excessive overtime. Other provisions of the UAW-GM pact likely to be carried over to Ford include: - A 3-percent increase in base wages in the first year of the contract. - Lump-sum payments equal to 3 percent of wages in the second and third years. - Continuation in cost-of-living adjustments for wages. - Pension improvements. - No change in health-care provisions. The contract will be reviewed by the Ford bargaining council on Tuesday. The council, made up of presidents and bargaining committee heads at the UAW's 79 local unions at Ford plants and offices, must approve it before the contract is sent out for ratification among Ford's 100,000 UAW members. Jack Hall, Ford's chief negotiator, said the contract ``has been achieved at a time when the competition in our industry has never been tougher, the cyclical nature of our business is a hard fact of life and world events have heightened economic uncertainties.'' In all, UAW contracts with the Big Three cover more than 450,000 active workers. The agreement with Ford, and its apparent similiarity with the GM contract, puts additional pressure on Chrysler, where about 60,000 hourly and salaried workers are covered by the UAW contract. The union has insisted that a contract it reaches with one of the companies will be the model for the other two. Chrysler has said the GM agreement appears to be very expensive.

DOC.HEAD: ENTel Sale Postponed for Up to One Month
DOC.TEXT: Sale of the state phone company ENTel was postponed for up to one month Sunday because the government could not agree to final terms with the U.S. and European buyers. After insisting for a year the sale would take place Oct. 8 to coincide with the birthday of party founder Juan Domingo Peron, President Carlos Menem said the transfer now will take place from 15 days to a month from now. A main obstacle is ENTel's rate structure, Public Works Minister Jose Dromi told reporters during breaks in negotiations that lasted all weekend. Thirty-one percent of customers' bills is taxed to support the national pension fund. Purchasers want the tax removed, or the government to hike rates an equivalent amount before they take over. Also, customers and many politicians are outraged by the 42 percent rate increase that took effect Sept. 24, bringing hikes this year to near 2,400 percent. ``That assures the private companies a profitability much higher than stipulated by the bid specifications,'' said Peronist Party Sen. Liliana Gurdulich, chairwoman of the bicameral State Reform Committee that monitors the sale of public companies. Sale of the Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones is one of the biggest privatization projects in the world. The aging, money-losing system of 3 million lines and 46,000 employees is to be divided into two sections. Investors have agreed to pay $594 million in cash and notes, and retire $5 billion of Argentina's foreign debt, for 60 percent of ENTel. The debt-equity swap is a way for the government to reduce a $66 billion foreign debt and for banks to get at least some value for loans trading on secondary markets as low as 12 cents on the dollar. Problems cropped up last Thursday when a group led by U.S.-based Manufacturers Hanover bank and Philadelphia-based telephone company Bell Atlantic Corp. failed to meet a deadline to make the down payment for ENTel's northern section and dropped out. That group was replaced by Italian and French telecommunications companies STET and Cables and Radio, respectively; U.S.-based J.P. Morgan & Co. bank and the Argentine ship and bank conglomerate Perez Companc. Another group led by Spain's telecommunications company Telefonica, U.S.-based Citibank and the Argentine construction and engineering company Techint won the bid for the southern section, but reportedly won't pay and take over until STET does likewise.
